finding: The rs11759769 variant at 6q16.1 revealed associations with migraine and was linked to the auditory, cingulo-opercular, and ventral multimodal networks, indicating genetic influences on sensory processing in migraines.
title: Genetic influences on the intrinsic and extrinsic functional organizations of the cerebral cortex

finding: The rs2971609 variant within the FHL5 gene at 6q16.1 was implicated in cerebrovascular traits and linked to cerebral blood flow, enhancing the understanding of its role in brain vascularity and associated disorders.
title: Genetic influences on the intrinsic and extrinsic functional organizations of the cerebral cortex

finding: This SNP was linked with decreased expression of BMP6 and IFNB1 in response to Mtb infection, highlighting its potential influence on inflammatory responses.
title: Mycobacterium tuberculosis-dependent Monocyte Expression Quantitative Trait Loci and Tuberculosis Pathogenesis

finding: Associated with the cis-regulation of MAS1 expression and the regulation of IL6, suggesting its involvement in the immunogenic response to Mtb.
title: Mycobacterium tuberculosis-dependent Monocyte Expression Quantitative Trait Loci and Tuberculosis Pathogenesis

finding: A novel locus found on chromosome 6, rs71717606 was noted in the GWAS for Hispanic ancestry with a P-value of 4.84 × 10−10. It was linked to the DCBLD1 gene, which is involved in development, marking it as an important genetic marker for dizziness phenotypes in this demographic.
title: GWAS of Chronic Dizziness in the Elderly Identifies Significant Loci Implicating MLLT10, BPTF, LINC01225, and ROS1

finding: Located on chromosome 6, rs72965321 was significant in the fine-mapping analysis indicating a correlation with skin color and anatomical brain characteristics, thus associating it with neurological functions linked to chronic dizziness.
title: GWAS of Chronic Dizziness in the Elderly Identifies Significant Loci Implicating MLLT10, BPTF, LINC01225, and ROS1

finding: The SNP rs2187668 was identified as a tag variant for determining HLA DR haplotypes in the context of Type 1 Diabetes (T1D). This variant contributed to the genetic risk score (T1DGRS) which was generated by incorporating previously published variants associated with T1D risk.
title: Estimating population level disease prevalence using genetic risk scores

finding: The SNP rs7454108 also served as a tag variant for HLA DR haplotypes in the T1D context. Similar to rs2187668, it was part of the composite genetic risk score (T1DGRS) focusing on the association with Type 1 Diabetes prevalence.
title: Estimating population level disease prevalence using genetic risk scores

finding: The sentinel rs78695099 was linked to smoking initiation, suggesting it may influence the effectiveness of varenicline by affecting the likelihood of taking up smoking.
title: Genome-wide association study of varenicline-aided smoking cessation

finding: In the analysis, it was reported that the T allele of the rs28986310 SNP was associated with increased risk of developing PTSD, indicated by a beta value of 0.31 and a highly significant p-value of 1.68e-11. Additionally, higher methylation levels at the intergenic cg14753356 site were linked to the T allele of rs28986310. This suggests a connection between DNA methylation at this locus and susceptibility to PTSD.
title: Epigenome-wide association studies identify novel DNA methylation sites associated with PTSD: A meta-analysis of 23 military and civilian cohorts

finding: Found to be associated with autoimmune inflammatory conditions and was an outlier variant with a substantial effect size in the analyses.
title: Using human genetics to understand the causes and consequences of circulating cardiac troponin I in the general population

finding: This variant was linked to higher odds for T2D and was associated with lower total circulating bilirubin levels, suggesting a possible pathway connecting bilirubin metabolism and diabetes risk.
title: Rare variant association analysis in 51,256 type 2 diabetes cases and 370,487 controls informs the spectrum of pathogenicity of monogenic diabetes genes

finding: The SNP rs13194805 was associated with mammographic density changes over time, which linked it to breast cancer risk, as indicated in the systematic review of Mokhtary et al. (2021). This finding highlighted the importance of genetic factors in modifying mammographic features that could impact the prediction of breast cancer incidence.
title: Use of repeated mammograms to evaluate risk of breast cancer: a systematic review of methods used in the literature

finding: The p.C282Y variant (rs1800562) was linked to high cumulative incidences of haemochromatosis diagnoses among males and females, with an incidence of 56.4% for males by age 80. This mutation was associated with higher mortality rates (33.1% in males vs. 25.4% without variants) and increased incidences of liver disease (20.3% vs. 8.3%) and joint replacements (27.9% vs. 17.1%), indicating significant morbidity related to this SNP.
title: HFE genotypes, haemochromatosis diagnosis and clinical outcomes to age 80: a prospective cohort study in UK Biobank

finding: The p.H63D variant (rs1799945) did not show statistically significant excess morbidity in terms of fatigue or depression. However, when analyzed alongside the p.C282Y variant, it was noted that individuals with the p.C282Y/p.H63D combinations did not show any additional adverse outcomes compared to controls, thus presenting a different clinical profile from homozygotes.
title: HFE genotypes, haemochromatosis diagnosis and clinical outcomes to age 80: a prospective cohort study in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs7756992 in the gene CDKAL1 showed significant associations in the liability GWAS for type 2 diabetes, despite not being identified in the conventional binary method. This finding was consistent with literature reports on the genetic basis of type 2 diabetes.
title: Genetic association studies using disease liabilities from deep neural networks

finding: The rs3734381 variant located in the CEP85L/PLN locus was associated with spatially resolved left ventricular wall thickness displaying an apical to basal gradient. This sentinel variant had been previously identified in relation to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) and QRS duration in earlier GWAS, but it had not been linked to left ventricular wall thickness or mass until now.
title: Genetic architecture of cardiac structure and function

finding: The association of rs9273368 (chr6:32658525) with type 1 diabetes (phecode 250.1) was noted, demonstrating a p-value of 4.23e-106, which also replicated findings regarding diabetes medication use from prior reports.
title: The Michigan Genomics Initiative: a biobank linking genotypes and electronic clinical records in Michigan Medicine patients

finding: The SNP rs9505286 on chromosome 6 reached genome-wide significance (p=4.3×10^-8) in the MetaSSA analysis. It was located in the intronic region of BMP6, with eQTLs linked to BMP6 and RREB1, both relevant to kidney disease through their roles in kidney fibrosis and type 2 diabetes.
title: Genetic Association and Transferability for Urinary Albumin-Creatinine Ratio as a Marker of Kidney Disease in four Sub-Saharan African Populations and non-continental Individuals of African Ancestry

finding: The SNP rs1268122 was identified as a male-specific genome-wide significant signal for CRF-vo2max on chromosome 6. It was associated with significant effect size heterogeneity and showed no correlation with other signals on the same chromosome.
title: The genetic case for cardiorespiratory fitness as a clinical vital sign and the routine prescription of physical activity in healthcare

finding: The male-specific SNP rs67693719 on chromosome 6 was significant for physical activity (PA) and showed no evidence for association in females, with significant heterogeneity present.
title: The genetic case for cardiorespiratory fitness as a clinical vital sign and the routine prescription of physical activity in healthcare

finding: The SNP rs10455872, located in the LPA gene, was found to exhibit a dominance effect for lipoprotein(a). Literature supported its association with elevated lipoprotein(a) levels and coronary disease risks, indicating its significant role in cardiovascular health.
title: Improved prediction of blood biomarkers using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs12206087 at 6q14.3 was associated with intelligence and cortical surface measurements. It was recognized as a novel loci relevant to mania distinct from other bipolar disorder associations.
title: Isolating the genetic component of mania in bipolar disorder

finding: The SNP rs2571381 was significantly associated with severe reactions to the COVID-19 vaccine, particularly in recipients of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, with a p-value of 1.16E-12. This SNP contributed to the observed increase in risk of severe reactions.
title: HLA-A*03:01 is associated with increased risk of fever, chills, and more severe reaction to Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccination

finding: The variant chr6:29820015:AAAAT:A was associated with severe difficulties following vaccination, showing statistical significance related to the HLA-G gene, contributing to a better understanding of genetic factors in vaccine reactions.
title: HLA-A*03:01 is associated with increased risk of fever, chills, and more severe reaction to Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccination

finding: This SNP was associated with membership in the high-gain weight cluster, indicating its role in the genetic determinants of adult weight trajectories.
title: The genetic architecture of changes in adiposity during adulthood

finding: SNP rs72560793 was identified as part of the shared genetic basis between head BMD and intracranial aneurysm (IA), highlighting its potential significance in vascular and bone health.
title: GWAS of ∼30,000 samples with bone mineral density at multiple skeletal sites and its clinical relevance on fracture prediction, genetic correlations and prioritization of drug targets

finding: The rs36215567 variant in the SYNE1 gene was associated with a significantly higher incidence of myocardial infarction (MI) in patients under 50 years old with a family history of premature atherosclerosis. The odds ratio (OR) compared to the control population was reported as 4.80 with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 1.43-14.45 (p=0.005). Additionally, when compared to an age- and gender-matched control group, the OR was 9.31 with a 95% CI of 1.64-95.41 (p=0.004). The study further confirmed this SNP as an independent risk factor for premature MI using a multivariable logistic regression model, yielding an OR of 13.86 (95% CI 1.64 - 117.45, p=0.016). This suggests that the variant rs36215567 may have a significant role in influencing the risk of MI among younger patients with a specific familial background.
title: SYNE1 gene novel variant is associated with myocardial infarction in young people with a family history of premature atherosclerosis

finding: The SNP rs9275602, located in the HLA region, was found to be associated with PSA levels, reflecting its inclusion among the PSA-associated variants that collectively explained a notable amount of PSA variation in studied cohorts.
title: Leveraging Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Towards Improving Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The variant rs926309 in JARID2 highlighted its significant association with PSA, emphasizing its role in understanding the genetic landscape surrounding PSA variation.
title: Leveraging Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Towards Improving Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The rs12333117 polymorphism was found to significantly influence the expression of the NRN1 gene in the prefrontal cortex (PFC) of schizophrenia patients treated with clozapine (SZ-Clz). It was demonstrated that incorporating this SNP into a model alongside LC1 scores enhanced the correlation with NRN1 gene expression (standardized β=-0.364, p=0.045). This variant was shown to alter transcription factor binding affinity and affected enhancer and promoter function in multiple tissues, indicating its role in regulatory mechanisms associated with schizophrenia.
title: CLOZAPINE-RELATED BRAIN NRN1 EXPRESSION PATTERNS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH METHYLATION AND GENETIC VARIANTS IN SCHIZOPHRENIA

finding: The rs2208870 SNP also significantly influenced the NRN1 gene expression in SZ-Clz individuals. When included in the model, it enhanced the prediction of NRN1 expression (standardized β=-0.404, p=0.029) alongside LC1 scores. This variant was similarly implicated in regulatory functions, including altering transcription factor binding and affecting gene expression related to schizophrenia.
title: CLOZAPINE-RELATED BRAIN NRN1 EXPRESSION PATTERNS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH METHYLATION AND GENETIC VARIANTS IN SCHIZOPHRENIA

finding: The study found that the TT genotype of rs1360780 interacted with experiences of child abuse to predict resting-state functional connectivity (rsFC) between the right centromedial amygdala and the right posterior insula. Specifically, TT allele carriers with a history of abuse demonstrated stronger rsFC, indicating a susceptibility to changes in emotional and bodily sensation processing. These findings underscored that such interactions might increase the risk for developing psychopathology, suggesting a link between FKBP5 genotype, early-life stress, and brain connectivity relevant to emotional processing.
title: The Interaction of Child Abuse and rs1360780 of the FKBP5 Gene is Associated with Amygdala Resting-State Functional Connectivity in Young Adults

finding: This SNP was associated with the PKHD1 gene, which is linked to polycystic liver disease and was observed to be enriched in the Finnish population. The minor allele frequency (MAF) for this variant was noted to be 0.00748 in the Finnish population, indicating its presence as a potentially significant heterozygous cause of cystic kidney disease.
title: Quantifying variant contributions in cystic kidney disease using national-scale whole genome sequencing

finding: The minor C-allele at rs2504706 was positively associated with higher intake of cereal (beta=0.058) and negatively associated with lower intake of coffee (beta=-0.034). This finding indicated a shared genetic construct where the allele was linked to dietary patterns across the two food types.
title: Increased brain volume from higher cereal and lower coffee intake: Shared genetic determinants and impacts on cognition and metabolism

finding: The SNP rs9281226 was identified within the HLA region and showed an association with hernia types. It was noted that it did not match well with known HLA-alleles, with only one having a significant correlation, demonstrating its potential relevance in the genetic mechanisms of hernias.
title: Comprehensive genome-wide association study of different forms of hernia identifies more than 80 associated loci

finding: This well-characterized SNP associated with OPRM1 was significant (p=1.63e-08) for opioid use disorder, marking it as a key genetic marker in addiction studies.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association meta-analysis of over 1 million subjects identifies loci underlying multiple substance use disorders

finding: This SNP was associated with cervical dysplasia and was located in the HLA region on chromosome 6, with a p-value of 9.1 × 10−9, indicating its potential relevance in the immune response related to cervical pathology.
title: GWAS meta-analysis and gene expression data link reproductive tract development, immune response and cellular proliferation/apoptosis with cervical cancer and clarify overlap with other cervical phenotypes

finding: This SNP, also located in the HLA region, was associated with cervical dysplasia with a p-value of 1.6 × 10−22, highlighting its importance in cervical disease mechanisms.
title: GWAS meta-analysis and gene expression data link reproductive tract development, immune response and cellular proliferation/apoptosis with cervical cancer and clarify overlap with other cervical phenotypes

finding: This SNP was strongly associated with cervical cancer (p-value 1.0 × 10−39) located in the HLA region, reinforcing the genetic impact on cervical disease.
title: GWAS meta-analysis and gene expression data link reproductive tract development, immune response and cellular proliferation/apoptosis with cervical cancer and clarify overlap with other cervical phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs9461856 was associated with ASD through the identification of infrequent but significant variants in SYNGAP1, a gene linked with ASD in over 50 studies. The study found that 17% of ASD cases displayed an overlapping NMI-SV with this GWAS SNP, establishing a stronger connection to ASD phenotypes.
title: Structural Variants Are a Major Component of the Missing Heritability of Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: The SNP rs2051449 marked an ASD-SV in the GRIK2 gene, present in 35% of cases. It was predicted to disrupt glutamate signaling critical for dendritic spine formation, highlighting its relevance to ASD pathology.
title: Structural Variants Are a Major Component of the Missing Heritability of Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: The SNP rs1040574 was reported as significant in both the GWAS for MDD PA-FGRS and case-control status, showing a beta of -0.011 with a p-value of 3.3 × 10−8 for PA-FGRS and a beta of -0.073 with p-value of 4.6 × 10−8 for case-control status. This SNP also exhibited a consistent sign in Howard et al.'s studies.
title: PA-FGRS is a novel estimator of pedigree-based genetic liability that complements genotype-based inferences into the genetic architecture of major depressive disorder

finding: The SNP rs3777421 was also significant in the MDD case-control analysis, demonstrating a beta of -0.073 and a p-value of 4.6 × 10−8. This SNP was consistent in findings reported by Howard et al. as well.
title: PA-FGRS is a novel estimator of pedigree-based genetic liability that complements genotype-based inferences into the genetic architecture of major depressive disorder

finding: The SNP rs1799971, located at the OPRM1 locus, was recognized as an original finding associated with opioid use disorder (OUD). It was part of the initial genome-wide association study (GWAS) on OUD.
title: Genome-wide analyses reveal novel opioid use disorder loci and genetic overlap with schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and major depression

finding: The SNP rs1799971 was identified in the gene encoding the mu opioid receptor (OPRM1) through the largest genome-wide association study of opioid use disorder (OUD), which included 15,756 cases and 99,039 controls. The study found this variant to have a statistically significant association with OUD, with a small effect size of standardized beta = -0.066. Despite this finding, the effect size was considered unlikely to be clinically meaningful, pointing towards the complexities associated with predicting OUD using genetic markers.
title: Genetic Data Can Lead to Medical Discrimination: Opioid Use Disorder as a Cautionary Tale

finding: The rs9381564 variant near the CD2AP gene was associated with longevity and belonged to the Longevity-group in the analysis.
title: The effect of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants on longevity

finding: The rs9275152 variant mapping to the HLA region has shown mixed associations affecting both AD-risk and longevity.
title: The effect of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants on longevity

finding: This SNP exhibited a genome-wide significant association with the immediate recall memory phenotype with a P value of 7.50E-11. It is located in an intron of the SMOC2 gene, associated with extracellular matrix assembly.
title: Genome-wide association study of Alzheimer’s disease brain imaging biomarkers and neuropsychological phenotypes in the EMIF-AD Multimodal Biomarker Discovery dataset

finding: The SNP rs3822960 was found to be G2-specific, indicating its involvement in the regulation of IgG glycosylation, specifically in the context of the galactosylation process.
title: Mapping of the gene network that regulates glycan clock of ageing

finding: The HMGA1 SNP rs41269028 was associated with the height of breast cancer patients. Women homozygous for the major allele (CC) had an average height of 162.29 cm ± 6.18, while carriers or homozygotes of the minor allele T (CT + TT) had a greater average height of 162.88 cm ± 6.001. This height difference was statistically significant (p = 0.005). The study found a greater proportion of tall women with breast cancer (11.9%) were carriers or homozygotes of the minor allele compared to short women (6.8%), with a p-value of 0.02 indicating a significant association. However, the genotypic effect of rs41269028 on breast cancer risk and survival was found to be insignificant (p = 0.602 and p = 0.439, respectively).
title: Tall women with breast cancer have poorer survival than short women

finding: The rs4151667 SNP was identified as part of the C2/BF genetic region, which relates to the H10 haplotype. The study found that drusen formation, present in 97 subjects, correlated with CFH risk, indicating that this specific SNP was involved in the genetic risks associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD), particularly in relation to soft drusen.
title: Systemic and Genetic Risk Factors for Reticular Macular Disease and Soft Drusen in Age-Related Macular Degeneration

finding: This SNP formed part of the seven loci shared between hypothyroidism and TSH levels, supporting the shared genetic architecture between these traits.
title: Uncovering the Shared Genetic Components of Thyroid Disorders and Reproductive Health

finding: The study reported that rs9277534 was strongly associated with HLA-DPB1 expression levels, classifying patients as having high or low expression mismatches based on their genotype at this SNP. Patients with the imputed rs9277534-G allele were categorized as high expression, while those with two rs9277534-A alleles were classified as low expression. This classification was pivotal in determining the hazards associated with donor-patient mismatches in HLA-DPB1, as it was linked to acute graft versus host disease and treatment-related mortality outcomes.
title: Machine Learning Insights into HLA Noncoding Sequence Mismatches and Their Impact on DPB1 Matching in Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation

finding: The SNP rs3844313 at HLA-DQB1 was the primary association found in African-ancestry individuals, with an odds ratio of 1.41, indicating a significant risk for AMD.
title: Distinctive cross-ancestry genetic architecture for age-related macular degeneration

finding: The rs9349379 variant was near PHACTR1/EDN1, previously noted for its non-coding variants in CAD studies.
title: Discovery and systematic characterization of risk variants and genes for coronary artery disease in over a million participants

finding: The analysis demonstrated that rs13195636 was associated with significant findings in schizophrenia and differential white blood cell (WBC) counts. Specifically, it had the smallest p-value in the schizophrenia GWAS and was identified as an influential outlier SNP which could cause bias through horizontal pleiotropy. When outliers were removed using the MR-PRESSO method, schizophrenia was suggested to increase lymphocyte count (beta=0.014; FDR adjusted p-val=0.010), monocyte count (beta=0.009; FDR adjusted p-val=0.045), and neutrophil count (beta=0.011; FDR adjusted p-val=0.028). The SNP is located in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) region, known for its role in neurodevelopment and immune regulation, potentially linking it to schizophrenia and immune response.
title: Bidirectional two-sample Mendelian randomization study of differential white blood cell count and schizophrenia

finding: The rs1799971 variant (A118G) in the OPRM1 gene was consistently associated with opioid addiction (OA) in the GENOA study, with a notable protective effect (G allele) reported (p=1.94x10^-6). Despite its previous identification as a significant variant, newer analyses indicated that it may not be the primary causal variant for OA in this locus.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study of opioid addiction: OPRM1 and Beyond

finding: The lead SNP rs9478500 in the OPRM1 gene demonstrated strong association with OA (p=2.56x10^-9) and was concluded to have a role in increasing OA risk with a beta coefficient of 0.136.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study of opioid addiction: OPRM1 and Beyond

finding: The SNP rs11308001 in IRF4 was associated with the phenotype of hair color and showed significant cross-ancestry heterogeneity in its effects, similar to other loci related to hair pigmentation.
title: Inter-population differences of allele frequency and regulome tagging are associated with the heterogeneity of loci identified by cross-ancestry genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs75932628, associated with the R47H variant, was implicated in affecting the production, expression, or turnover of TREM2 and was mentioned concerning its involvement in ligand binding. It was positively linked with TREM2 status in Alzheimer's disease.
title: Alterations in the Brain Lipidome of Alzheimer’s Disease Donors with Rare TREM2 Risk Variants

finding: The SNP rs4580892 was found within the intron of the RSPO3 gene and was identified as the top signal shared between type 2 diabetes (T2D) and fracture risk. Specifically, the rs4580892_T allele was associated with an increased risk of T2D (Odds Ratio = 1.041227, P = 8.46×10^-9) while showing a decreased risk of fracture (Odds Ratio = 0.944, P = 3.68×10^-10). This finding indicated an inverse effect between T2D and fracture risk, contributing to the understanding of the 'diabetic bone paradox'.
title: Deciphering the relationship between type 2 diabetes and fracture risk: the genetic and observational evidences

finding: The SNP rs9349379, a non-coding variant in the third intron of PHACTR1, was identified as the causal variant for associations with five vascular diseases. The association replicated by the TargetAge examines its link to coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, intermediate coronary syndrome, and coronary atherosclerosis, while also having implications for ischemic stroke and large artery stroke.
title: Integrative analysis of GWAS and co-localisation data suggests novel genes associated with age-related multimorbidity

finding: This SNP showed significant pleiotropic associations, particularly with cardiometabolic traits, indicating a shared genetic architecture with anxiety disorders.
title: Genome-wide association study of major anxiety disorders in 122,341 European-ancestry cases identifies 58 loci and highlights GABAergic signaling

finding: The variant rs199585353 in the PRIM2 gene was identified as significantly associated with ischemic stroke in European Caucasians, showing a minor allele frequency of 0.25% in stroke cases and absent in controls, with a p-value of 8.28 x 10^-8.
title: Exome Array Analysis of 9,721 ischemic stroke cases from the SiGN Consortium

finding: SNP rs62619974 in the MEP1A gene was significantly associated with ischemic stroke, with strong association observed within African American subjects, indicating relevant population stratification.
title: Exome Array Analysis of 9,721 ischemic stroke cases from the SiGN Consortium

finding: In the study, rs3129888 was identified as a significant risk variant for sarcoidosis, particularly in the European American (EA) cohort, and was also replicated in the African American (AA) cohort. The G allele of rs3129888 was shown to increase the risk of sarcoidosis, consistent with findings from prior literature on Lofgren's syndrome.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: rs9269233 was the most significant SNP associated with sarcoidosis and remained significantly associated even after adjustment for related HLA alleles, indicating it serves as an independent risk allele in the HLA region.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: This SNP showed significant association with sarcoidosis susceptibility across both EA and AA cohorts, although it did not reach genome-wide significance thresholds, it was acknowledged for potential risk.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: This novel risk variant was found to be significantly associated with sarcoidosis in both the EA and AA cohorts, indicating its importance as a new risk locus.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: Found to be significantly associated with sarcoidosis, this SNP was notable for its eQTL status in lung tissue.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: This SNP remained significant for sarcoidosis even after adjustments were made for related genetic variants, suggesting its relevance in the pathology of the disease.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: This SNP was noted for its significant colocalization with HLA-DRA expression levels, suggesting a functional role in the gene expression influencing sarcoidosis.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs3176326 in the CDKN1A locus had a significant association with unclassified HF in the MVP cohort of African Americans after Bonferroni correction, demonstrating its relevance across populations.
title: Genetic Architecture of Heart Failure with Preserved versus Reduced Ejection Fraction

finding: The SNP rs4151702 within CDKN1A was test-wise significant after Bonferroni correction in the African American cohort, supporting its association with HFrEF.
title: Genetic Architecture of Heart Failure with Preserved versus Reduced Ejection Fraction

finding: The index SNP rs71557378 was identified on chromosome 6 with a genome-wide significance of p = 1.97×10−8. This SNP was part of a locus associated with suicide attempt (SA), highlighting its potential role in suicidal behavior.
title: Genome-wide association study meta-analysis of suicide attempt in 43,871 cases identifies twelve genome-wide significant loci

finding: The SNP rs9968910 exhibited higher allele frequency among clinical hereditary hemochromatosis patients and was associated with blood donor eligibility through its effects on iron metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals the unique genetic structure of active blood donors

finding: The SNP rs9272324 was significantly associated with the blood donor endpoint in the HLA-DQA1 gene context. Its relationship with autoimmunity was strong, underscoring its importance in donor health profiles.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals the unique genetic structure of active blood donors

finding: The SNP rs487152 was identified as a variant strongly associated with increased serum lipoprotein A (Lp(a)) levels in the context of the Lipoprotein A cluster. It was associated with T2D risk, elevated serum Lp(a) levels, coronary artery disease (CAD), and chronic kidney disease (CKD). The finding suggests a genetic pathway linking increased Lp(a) levels with the risk of these conditions. Specifically, the T2D-risk-increasing allele of this variant was confirmed through a significant association in the UK Biobank with a GWAS p-value of 4.06×10<sup>−1586</sup>. Despite the associations, the mechanism that relates these findings to insulin deficiency was noted to be unclear.
title: High-throughput Genetic Clustering of Type 2 Diabetes Loci Reveals Heterogeneous Mechanistic Pathways of Metabolic Disease

finding: The SNP rs7749444, located near PRIM2BP, was associated with olfactory bulb volume, showing a higher effect size in males (β = 0.06) than in females (β = 0.01), with a significant sex difference (P = 1.17 × 10⁻³).
title: Genome-wide analysis identifies 66 variants underlying anatomical variation in human neuroendocrine structures and reveals links to testosterone

finding: The SNP rs2184968, an intronic variant of CENPW, showed a significant association with pituitary gland volume (β = 0.16, MAF = 0.45), linking it to testosterone-related traits.
title: Genome-wide analysis identifies 66 variants underlying anatomical variation in human neuroendocrine structures and reveals links to testosterone

finding: The SNP rs1799964, located in the Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha gene, was similarly found to be associated with the risk of developing microcephaly in newborns exposed to Zika virus. The study conducted by Santos et al. (2019) indicated that this genetic variant plays a role in modifying the neurodevelopmental outcomes following prenatal viral infections.
title: Building a growing genomic data repository for maternal and fetal health through the PING Consortium

finding: This SNP was newly identified as associated with coffee consumption, suggesting its genetic relevance in this phenotype.
title: Habitual Coffee Consumption Increases Risks for Metabolic Diseases: Genome-wide Association Studies and a Phenotype-wide Two Sample Mendelian Randomization Analysis

finding: The SNP rs4713916 in the FKBP5 gene was identified as a potential genetic predictor of varying responses to inhaled corticosteroids among patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). This finding was particularly relevant to the treatment efficacy and individual variability observed in COPD patients, suggesting a genetic influence on therapeutic outcomes.
title: Anomalous epithelial variations and ectopic inflammatory response in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

finding: The variant rs200999181 was recognized as the only variant in its cluster with the strongest effect size of 0.334, indicating a strong positive association with the analyzed traits.
title: CLUSTERING OF RARE VARIANTS FOR CAUSAL VARIANTS IDENTIFICATION AND EFFECT DIRECTION CLASSIFICATION

finding: This variant, together with four others, formed a cluster with a moderate positive effect size of 0.173, further indicating its potential relevance in association with blood pressure traits.
title: CLUSTERING OF RARE VARIANTS FOR CAUSAL VARIANTS IDENTIFICATION AND EFFECT DIRECTION CLASSIFICATION

finding: rs76146749 was included in a cluster that had a moderate positive effect size of 0.173, contributing to the understanding of genetic influences on blood pressure.
title: CLUSTERING OF RARE VARIANTS FOR CAUSAL VARIANTS IDENTIFICATION AND EFFECT DIRECTION CLASSIFICATION

finding: Engaged in the cluster with a moderate positive effect size of 0.173, rs200401514 provided additional evidence for its role in influencing blood pressure traits.
title: CLUSTERING OF RARE VARIANTS FOR CAUSAL VARIANTS IDENTIFICATION AND EFFECT DIRECTION CLASSIFICATION

finding: This variant was part of the signal cluster exhibiting a moderate positive effect size of 0.173, marking its significance in association with blood pressure traits.
title: CLUSTERING OF RARE VARIANTS FOR CAUSAL VARIANTS IDENTIFICATION AND EFFECT DIRECTION CLASSIFICATION

finding: This SNP was identified as associated with acetate, being the only novel genome-wide significant SNP identified in relation to this metabolite specific to South Asians. No previous associations had been documented regarding its role.
title: Metabolic Drivers of Dysglycemia in Pregnancy: Ethnic-Specific GWAS of 146 Metabolites and 1-Sample Mendelian Randomisation Analyses in a UK Multi-Ethnic Birth Cohort

finding: The SNP rs78636169, located near the JARID2 gene, demonstrated a significant association with tau deposition in Alzheimer's disease through a genome-wide association study, with a p-value of 5.76×10^-10. This finding remained significant after adjustments for APOE-ε4 status, indicating its independent effect on tau pathology.
title: Genome-wide scan of Flortaucipir PET levels finds JARID2 associated with cerebral tau deposition

finding: The minor T-allele of SNP rs2523425 exerted a risk for SS by decreasing TRIM27 gene expression. This association confirmed previous reports of TRIM27 being down-regulated in SS patients and indicated a genetic predisposition to altered immune responses.
title: An integrative multi-omics approach in Sjögren’s Syndrome identifies novel genetic drivers with regulatory function and disease-specificity

finding: The minor T-allele of SNP rs7769693 was linked to increased SS risk due to decreased methylation levels at the PSMB8 gene, indicating that it might enhance risks through epigenetic alteration.
title: An integrative multi-omics approach in Sjögren’s Syndrome identifies novel genetic drivers with regulatory function and disease-specificity

finding: The intronic variant rs9349379 in <italic>PHACTR1</italic> was deemed a strong candidate for being causal for migraine with a PIP of 1.00, having been implicated in multiple vascular diseases that may influence migraine risk.
title: Fine-mapping a genome-wide meta-analysis of 98,374 migraine cases identifies 181 sets of candidate causal variants

finding: The SNP rs78459872 was identified as having a heterogeneous effect on smoking cessation (SC) between late-onset and early-onset smokers when using dichotomized CPD. However, it lacked genome-wide significance for alternatives and illustrated the complexities in genetic effects depending on the smoking behavior being analyzed.
title: Investigating heterogeneous genetic effects contributing to smoking behaviors

finding: This SNP exhibited associations with increased asthma susceptibility and severity through risk alleles identified in several studies. Although the specific details regarding its impact on PGAP3 expression were less reported compared to rs2517 and rs955, it also contributed to the patterns of asthma exacerbation observed.
title: PGAP3 regulates human bronchial epithelial cell mRNAs present in asthma and respiratory virus reference data sets

finding: The variant rs3798220, a missense variant in the LPA gene, had a strong effect with 1.18 attributable DALYs through ischemic heart disease, significantly impacting overall disability-adjusted life years.
title: Genetic risk factors have a substantial impact on healthy life years

finding: The SNP rs145575084 was associated with seronegative rheumatoid arthritis (RA) where it showed the strongest association linked to the MICA gene. This finding was part of a broader association profile that included SNPs ranging from the HLA-C gene to the MICA gene, demonstrating the implications of this SNP in the context of autoimmune diseases.
title: Phenome-wide HLA association study of Finnish biobank participants reveals infection-autoimmune disease links and modifier effects between HLA genes and alleles

finding: The TSH-increasing allele of the intronic SNP rs1743963 in SGK1 was associated with a decreased risk of both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism. The findings in the phenome-wide association study (PheWAS) indicated an association with increased calcium levels.
title: Genome-wide association study of thyroid-stimulating hormone highlights new genes, pathways and associations with thyroid disease susceptibility and age-of-onset

finding: In the both-controls GWAS scenario, rs36058333 was associated with the HLA-B locus and reported a similar λGC-adjusted p-value, odds ratio, and direction of effect compared to the internal-controls GWAS results, supporting its relevance to psoriatic arthritis.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: Similar to rs36058333, rs4418214 showed strong association with the HLA-B locus in the both-controls GWAS, replicating the findings from the internal-controls analysis regarding psoriatic arthritis.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: This SNP was associated with TRAF3IP2 in both the both-controls and external-controls scenarios, replicating the internal-controls GWAS results and further indicating its linkage to psoriatic arthritis.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: In the both-controls scenario, rs3115628 related to the HLA-G locus achieved genome-wide significance, demonstrating its strong connection to psoriatic arthritis.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: In the TSIM Joint and TSIM Meta GWAS, rs17211699 related to HLA-DQB1 replicated findings from the published meta-analysis, confirming its relevance in pSSNS.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: This SNP was associated with NFKBIL1 and similarly replicated in the TSIM Joint and TSIM Meta analyses, demonstrating its significance in pSSNS studies.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: As part of CALHM6, rs2637678 was successfully replicated in both TSIM analyses, indicating its importance in the genetic landscape of pSSNS.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: The genetic variant rs13191659, which is mapped to the LINC00240 gene, was found to be associated with both Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and falls. This SNP showed statistical significance in the GWAS analysis for MS (p < 5e-8) and for falls (p < 5e-5). The LINC00240 gene is known for its role in total iron binding capacity, folic acid deficiency anemia, and mean corpuscular volume.
title: Pleiotropic Genetic Effects between Multiple Sclerosis and Musculoskeletal Traits

finding: The rs2023239 polymorphism was found to have a protective effect regarding the risk for schizophrenia-spectrum disorders (SSD). It was observed that G-allele carriers exhibited higher pattern intensity index (PII) scores compared to AA-homozygotes, indicating greater dermatoglyphic complexity which is linked with lower SSD risk. This suggests a significant modulation effect between PII and SSD risk, where higher PII in G-allele carriers correlated with a reduced susceptibility to SSD.
title: Genetic and neurodevelopmental markers in schizophrenia-spectrum disorders: analysis of the combined role of the Cannabinoid Receptor 1 gene (CNR1) and dermatoglyphics

finding: The rs806379 polymorphism was associated with an increased risk for SSD. T-allele carriers were more prevalent among SSD patients compared to healthy controls, and it was linked with lower total a-b ridge count (TABRC) in healthy controls, suggesting an adverse impact on dermatoglyphic measures. This finding highlighted the risk effect of this SNP on the predisposition to SSD.
title: Genetic and neurodevelopmental markers in schizophrenia-spectrum disorders: analysis of the combined role of the Cannabinoid Receptor 1 gene (CNR1) and dermatoglyphics

finding: The SNP rs10455872 was identified as a causal variant associated with 6 trait pairs, specifically highlighting its role in abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and shared genetic pathways with other cardiometabolic traits.
title: Shared Genetic Susceptibility between Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm and Cardiometabolic Traits

finding: The SNP rs140570886 was shared among 4 trait pairs and identified as a causal variant, specifically linking to multiple traits relating to AAA and cardiometabolic disorders.
title: Shared Genetic Susceptibility between Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm and Cardiometabolic Traits

finding: The SNP rs3124784 was noted to be shared among 3 trait pairs, indicating its role as a causal variant in the genetic landscape of AAA and its associations with cardiometabolic traits.
title: Shared Genetic Susceptibility between Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm and Cardiometabolic Traits

finding: The SNP rs361525 in the gene TNF was identified to influence the risk of liver disease, highlighting its potential impact on glucagon dynamics in hepatic function.
title: Studies to develop a glucagon sensitivity test in humans: The GLUSENTIC study protocol

finding: This SNP was strongly associated with childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) at P=8.23 X 10-9 and an odds ratio of 1.27, located in the intergenic region between MYB and HBS1L. The association was primarily driven by Non-Latino White (NLW) participants in the meta-analysis.
title: Genome-wide trans-ethnic meta-analysis identifies novel susceptibility loci for childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia

finding: Similar to rs1544730, this locus showed a positive association with chronic dry cough, linking it to PREP and meeting a Bonferroni significance threshold.
title: Genomics of chronic cough unravels neurological pathways

finding: The eRNA-QTL rs62431527 exhibited strong colocalization with ovarian cancer, suggesting its involvement in increasing cancer susceptibility.
title: Enhancer RNA transcriptome-wide association study reveals an atlas of pan-cancer susceptibility eRNAs

finding: The rs9388451 SNP, linked to the HEY2 gene, was evaluated and found to segregate in a Mendelian manner among the family members. While its role appeared to be less directly associated with the immediate inheritance pattern of Brugada Syndrome, it contributed to the overall understanding of the genetic risk factors present in this family.
title: Additional Evidence Implicating GPD1L in the Pathogenesis of Brugada Syndrome in A Large Multi-generational Family

finding: The SNP rs9503939 located in an intergenic region was associated with study-wide significance in non-cognitive measures and showed suggestive associations with CSF amyloid-β levels.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: The SNP rs1065272, located in the 3' UTR of BACH2, was significant in relation to Parietal Lobe Cortical Thickness and showed neuroprotective effects in the later stages of AD.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: The SNP rs9265235, located near HLA-B, maintained study-wide significance in cognitive measures.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: The SNP rs9277531 near HLA-DPB1 was also significant in cognitive measures, showing a potential interaction with AD pathology.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: The variant rs9383938 at the ESR1 locus was significantly associated with the presence of TP53 mutations overall, with P values of 6.8×10^-5 in the multi-ancestry study and 9.8×10^-8 in the MyBrCa study, as well as with TP53 gain of function mutations (P value 8.4×10^-6).
title: Association of ESR1 germline variants with TP53 somatic variants in breast tumors in a genome-wide study

finding: In the MyBrCa study, variant rs9479090 was associated with TP53 mutations (P value 2.8×10^-7), marking it as significant within the scope of this research.
title: Association of ESR1 germline variants with TP53 somatic variants in breast tumors in a genome-wide study

finding: The HLA signal was associated with a decreased risk of chronic sputum production. The amino acid change linked to this SNP was threonine to arginine at codon 233 of exon 5 of HLA-DRB1. This was illustrated by an odds ratio of 0.91, indicating a protective effect.
title: Genome-wide association study of chronic sputum production implicates loci involved in mucus production and infection

finding: The SNP rs13195402, identified as a missense variant in the gene BTN2A1, was associated with bipolar disorder (BD) at genome-wide significance. Its association was noted to be distinct from the classical component of the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) loci, with no influence observed from the structural alleles of the C4A gene or its expression. The finding elucidated the role of rs13195402 in BD, marking a significant step in understanding the genetic underpinnings of the disorder.
title: Genome-wide association study of over 40,000 bipolar disorder cases provides new insights into the underlying biology

finding: The rs139586367 variant in the UFL1 gene had an exceptionally high odds ratio of 284.06 in individuals diagnosed with lymphoid neoplasms and prostate cancer.
title: Assessment of Genetic Susceptibility to Multiple Primary Cancers through Whole-Exome Sequencing in Two Large Multi-Ancestry Studies

finding: As the lead SNP for the RUNX2 gene, rs2790102 had a genome-wide significant association with BAG (p=8.92x10^-9). This SNP was linked to a decrease in brain age of 0.15 years associated with the effective A allele, emphasizing the genetic influence on brain health.
title: Genetic architecture of brain age and its casual relations with brain and mental disorders

finding: The IL17A rs2275913 minor allele variant was identified as a significant risk factor for fibrosis progression in MASLD patients. Those carrying the A allele (A/A and A/G genotypes) showed higher liver stiffness and more severe fibrosis compared to individuals with the homozygous major allele genotype (G/G) as assessed by fibroscan. Statistical analysis indicated a significant association between this SNP genotype and liver fibrosis with a glm adjusted p-value of 0.029.
title: Mycobiome Dysbiosis and Genetic Predisposition for Elevated IL-17A Drive Fibrosis in MASLD

finding: The rare variant rs144171242 at 6p21.1 was identified as being significant for PUV with a <italic>P</italic>-value of 2.02x10<sup>-8</sup> and an odds ratio of 7.2 in the mixed ancestry cohort, mapping to the <italic>PTK7</italic> gene, which is involved in embryonic development. The replication in the European cohort showed a <italic>P</italic>-value of 4.5x10<sup>-3</sup> and an odds ratio of 2.17, supporting its role in the risk of PUV.
title: Mixed ancestry analysis of whole-genome sequencing reveals common, rare, and structural variants associated with posterior urethral valves

finding: This SNP, associated with TNFAIP3, significantly increased neutrophil extracellular traps and citrullinated epitopes in SLE patients. It is considered a crucial risk allele in SLE pathogenesis.
title: A multilayered post-GWAS analysis pipeline defines functional variants and target genes for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

finding: The SNP rs72856706, located in an intronic region of the CCHCR1 gene, was associated with testosterone levels and COVID-19 critical illness. The findings indicated a positive association, with a beta value of 0.029 for testosterone (P=7.307E-09) and a beta value of 0.614 for COVID-19 ICU admission (P=9.15E-18). The study reported that this gene, known for its role in promoting steroidogenesis, was critically relevant for understanding the connection between testosterone levels and severe COVID-19 outcomes. However, the association with COVID-19 susceptibility was less significant, presenting a beta value of 0.039 (P=3.44E-07), and no significant association was found for COVID-19 respiratory failure (Beta=0.052, P=0.58). Thus, the findings provided support for a causal role of testosterone on COVID-19 critical illness, identifying CCHCR1 as a significant genetic locus in this relationship.
title: Genetically determined serum testosterone level and Covid-19 illness level: A mendelian randomization study

finding: rs2229523 was identified as a cis-pQTL for CD73, with the G allele associated with lower plasma levels of CD73. This was the first reporting of rs2229523 as a pQTL for circulatory protein levels, although it had previously been noted as an eQTL affecting NT5E mRNA expression.
title: Common variation in a long non-coding RNA gene modulates variation of circulating TGF-β2 levels in metastatic colorectal cancer patients (Alliance)

finding: The SNP rs7767396 was validated as a cis-pQTL for circulating VEGF-A, corroborating prior reports of its association with plasma levels in patients with pancreatic cancer.
title: Common variation in a long non-coding RNA gene modulates variation of circulating TGF-β2 levels in metastatic colorectal cancer patients (Alliance)

finding: The SNP rs473267 was identified both as a locus for anxiety (ANX) and shared between anxiety and schizophrenia (SCZ). It was associated with the DOPEY1 and PGM3 genes and was categorized under the exonic region.
title: Identification of Novel Genomic Loci for Anxiety and Extensive Genetic Overlap with Psychiatric Disorders

finding: The SNP rs3798220, located in the LPA gene, also demonstrated a significant association with HF, indicated by a P-value of 6.74×10^-51.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide analysis identified novel risk loci and candidate drugs for heart failure

finding: The rs13190937 SNP at the ZSCAN23 locus was associated with increased expression of ZSCAN23 in pancreatic tissue and had a significant p-value of 1.5 × 10^-8, indicating a potential link with longevity. Its associations included celiac disease and intestinal malabsorption.
title: Genetic associations with human longevity are enriched for oncogenic genes

finding:
The study identified that the noncoding variant rs557011, located between the HLA-DQA1 and HLA-DRB1 alleles, was associated with 
Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. This finding supports earlier reports by Sveinbjornsson et al. regarding the association of the HLA class II allele DQA1*03 with Mtb infection.
title: Expression of specific HLA class II alleles is associated with an increased risk for active tuberculosis and a distinct gene expression profile

finding: The SNP rs62401887 was associated with the hepatic biological age gap (BAG) and mapped to the MRS2 gene. It had a deleterious score of 14.89 and demonstrated significant eQTL effects (P-value=1.09×10^-10), indicating its relevance in magnesium ion transport.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Biological Age in Nine Human Organ Systems

finding: The association of rs11545686 with susceptibility to MPO-ANCA positive AAV was confirmed in the Japanese population, showing a significant odds ratio of 1.74 (95% CI 1.40-2.16). This SNP served as a tag for the HLA-DQA1*03:02 allele.
title: Association of HLA-class II alleles with risk of relapse in myeloperoxidase-antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody positive vasculitis in the Japanese population

finding: The SNP rs79919786 associated with ECHDC1 was positively found to involve in ethylmalonate conversion, suggesting its metabolic implications.
title: Genome-wide association study of 1,391 plasma metabolites in 6,136 Finnish men identifies 303 novel signals and provides biological insights into human diseases

finding: The SNP rs9505982 associated with PCMT1 was linked to S-adenosylhomocysteine levels, suggesting its role in methylation processes.
title: Genome-wide association study of 1,391 plasma metabolites in 6,136 Finnish men identifies 303 novel signals and provides biological insights into human diseases

finding: The rs9322319 SNP associated with RMND1 had a significant association with endometriosis, shown by a p-value of 2.86E-08. This SNP was close to a previously identified SYNE1 locus, reinforcing established genetic links to the condition.
title: Expanding the genetic landscape of endometriosis: Integrative -omics analyses uncover key pathways from a multi-ancestry study of over 900,000 women

finding: The study demonstrated that the imputed HLA-B27 status was more strongly related to the risk of Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) than rs9266267, with a p-value of 2.5×10⁻¹⁹⁸ compared to the p-value of 2.2×10⁻³⁰⁸ for self-reported AS. The association signal at rs9266267 was attenuated after conditioning on HLA-B27 status (p = 0.63), while the HLA-B27 risk remained strongly significant, indicating that the interaction with sex related to rs9266267 was likely influenced by HLA-B27.
title: HLA-B27 and not variation in MICA is responsible for genotype by sex interaction in risk of Ankylosing Spondylitis

finding: The SNP rs2235215 near MYLIP (IDOL) was associated with LDL metabolism, reinforcing its part in cholesterol homeostasis and interactions with other key LDL-processing genes in cardiovascular risk.
title: Lipo-proteomic and metabolic fine-mapping of genetic lipid risk loci

finding: The SNP rs56076919 located in the COL11A2 gene on chromosome 6 displayed a significant association with knee pain, with a p value of 9.82 × 10^-12. COL11A2 plays a role in collagen X1 composition, which is implicated in cartilage integrity and has been linked to OA.
title: A Genome-wide Association Study Identifies Novel Genetic Variants Associated with Knee Pain in the UK Biobank (N = 441,757)

finding: The SNP rs687878 within the SUPT3H gene on chromosome 6 displayed a p value of 2.38 × 10^-8, linking it to knee pain. SUPT3H is involved in transcriptional regulation, and its dysregulation might impact gene expression related to cartilage and inflammation.
title: A Genome-wide Association Study Identifies Novel Genetic Variants Associated with Knee Pain in the UK Biobank (N = 441,757)

finding: The SNP rs17587 was found to have a statistically significant association with asthma, indicating its potential involvement in the disease. It was noted that this variant is very rare in the gnomAD population, exhibiting a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 1.4e-05. Furthermore, rs17587 was previously proposed to increase the risk of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) among the Han Chinese ethnicity from Yunnan and was also linked to vitiligo in the Saudi community. These findings suggested a possible shared mechanism between asthma and other autoimmune diseases.
title: PWAS Hub: Exploring Gene-Based Associations of Common Complex Diseases

finding: Similar to rs2693698, the SNP rs13195401 showed an effect on bipolar disorder (BD). Exclusion of this SNP led to a statistically significant change in causal effect estimates for BD on poverty, with a result of B=0.031 and p=0.041.
title: The impact of poverty on mental illness: Emerging evidence of a causal relationship

finding: The SNP rs1906252 was implicated in the analysis concerning obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Leaving out this SNP resulted in a 15% increase in the causal effect estimate of poverty on OCD.
title: The impact of poverty on mental illness: Emerging evidence of a causal relationship

finding: The study demonstrated that rs10455872, an intronic SNP associated with Lp(a) concentration, was investigated as a genetic instrument in the context of two-sample Mendelian randomization analyses. Despite its strong association with Lp(a), the analyses did not support a causal relationship between Lp(a) and the risks of new-onset type 2 diabetes (T2D) nor non-alcoholic liver disease (NAFLD). This finding was consistent with previous work that relied solely on rs10455872.
title: Associations of Very Low Lipoprotein(a) Levels With Risks Of New-Onset Diabetes And Non-Alcoholic Liver Disease

finding: The SNP rs988551 in LAMA2 was identified as the most significant SNP associated with gestational hypertension (Trait ID: acog_PEgHTN_7) from a meta-analysis involving Europe, Africa, and Admixed Americans. It had a P-value of 4.7×10^-9. Additionally, PheWAS results demonstrated its association with other hypertension-related traits, having a P-value less than 1×10^-3. LAMA2 was also implicated as a gene dysregulated in preeclampsia.
title: Searching and visualizing genetic associations of pregnancy traits by using GnuMoM2b

finding: The SNP rs9349050 was identified as a significant genetic variant associated with MDGA1 protein levels and consequently with the metabolite 1-Arachidonoylglycerol (1-AG). The association suggested that the genetic variant was an instrumental variable that influenced both the protein and metabolite levels, illustrating a potential genetic basis for the co-regulation of protein-metabolite pairs in the context of neurodevelopmental processes.
title: Longitudinal analysis of genetic and environmental interplay in human metabolic profiles and the implication for metabolic health

finding: The rs10455872 SNP was found to be independently associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), contributing to the understanding that this locus is relevant to the pathogenesis of AAA. The identification of this SNP was part of a broader genetic analysis that uncovered 144 associations, including 97 previously unreported loci associated with AAA. This finding emphasized the involvement of various biological pathways in the disease, particularly lipid metabolism, vascular development and remodeling, and inflammation.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS deciphers genetic architecture of abdominal aortic aneurysm and highlights PCSK9 as a therapeutic target

finding: The stop gain variant rs3130453 in the CCHCR1 gene was associated with a marginal increase in psoriasis risk (OR=1.49, pval=7.7e-20). However, its effect size was significantly increased in the presence of missense variants in MUC22 and HSPA1L, revealing a synergistic epistasis, with ORs of 3.2 and 3.1 respectively for homozygotes carrying the minor alleles.
title: Atlas of epistasis

finding: The missense variant rs3094672 in MUC22 was involved in an interaction with the CCHCR1 stop gain variant rs3130453, amplifying the effect size from a marginal association to a strong association (OR=3.2) when combined with two minor alleles.
title: Atlas of epistasis

finding: The missense variant rs2227956 in HSPA1L also interacted with the CCHCR1 stop gain variant rs3130453, leading to a notable increase in the effect on psoriasis risk (OR=3.1) in the presence of two minor alleles, illustrating a case of synergistic epistasis.
title: Atlas of epistasis

finding: The missense variant rs2229094 was shown to affect the association of the rs2272596 variant with psoriasis risk in an antagonistic manner, where carrying the common allele decreased risk compared to the presence of the minor allele that dramatically increased risk (OR=4.82 for double homozygotes).
title: Atlas of epistasis

finding: The SNP rs1359232 was associated with the MECPP_MEHPP ratio linked to the SLC17A1 gene, identified as a positive original finding with an effect size of -0.134 and a p-value of 4.58E-17.
title: Common genetic variants associated with urinary phthalate levels in children: a genome-wide study

finding: The SNP rs6921438 was found to have the strongest association with VEGF levels at both visit 1 and 2, demonstrating a P-value of 7.94×10^-30 at visit 1 and 2.49×10^-28 at visit 2. This association confirmed a cis-acting genetic influence on VEGF during pregnancy.
title: Genetic Associations with Dynamic Placental Proteins Identify Causal Biomarkers for Hypertension in Pregnancy

finding: At the VEGFA locus, rs4349809 showed significant association with sFlt-1 levels at visit 1, with a P-value of 2.89×10^-8. Although it was not significantly associated at visit 2, its correlation with VEGF levels remained, indicating a genetic interplay affecting angiogenic regulation during pregnancy.
title: Genetic Associations with Dynamic Placental Proteins Identify Causal Biomarkers for Hypertension in Pregnancy

finding: The variant rs981087 located near CGA was significantly associated with fβHCG levels at visit 1, evidenced by a P-value of 1.12×10^-8. This underscores the genetic contributions to hormone regulation during pregnancy.
title: Genetic Associations with Dynamic Placental Proteins Identify Causal Biomarkers for Hypertension in Pregnancy

finding: The SNP rs7766070, situated within the CDKAL1 gene, was significantly associated with GDM risk, showing an odds ratio (OR) of 1.27 and a p-value of 8.07×10^-12.
title: Genome-wide association and Mendelian randomisation analysis among 30,699 Chinese pregnant women identifies novel genetic and molecular risk factors for gestational diabetes and glycaemic traits

finding: The SNP rs145348074 was found to be genome-wide significant in association with cognitive impairment-free survival time, linking it to the SHISA6 gene, a candidate gene for Alzheimer's disease.
title: Genetic variants in the SHISA6 gene are associated with delayed cognitive impairment in two family datasets

finding: The study identified rs706954, located <5kb downstream of VGLL2, which showed a significant interaction with periconceptional alcohol use (p<sub>GE</sub>=4.62×10<sup>−6</sup>). The minor allele (G) of this SNP was associated with higher odds of non-syndromic cleft lip with or without cleft palate (NSCL/P) in individuals with alcohol exposure but lower odds in individuals without such exposure.
title: Genome-wide interaction study implicates VGLL2 and alcohol exposure and PRL and smoking in orofacial cleft risk

finding: The SNP rs35097027, located upstream of PRL, showed significant interactions with maternal smoking (p<sub>GE</sub>=1.96×10<sup>−5</sup>). The minor allele (C) conferred higher odds of cleft lip/palate for individuals with maternal smoking while reversing to lower odds in individuals without maternal smoking.
title: Genome-wide interaction study implicates VGLL2 and alcohol exposure and PRL and smoking in orofacial cleft risk

finding: At the 6q21 locus, rs6929494 demonstrated a significant interaction concerning periconceptional alcohol use (p<sub>GE</sub>=1.18×10<sup>−5</sup>). The major allele (A) posed higher odds of NSCL/P in individuals exposed to alcohol, with a protective effect noted in the absence of alcohol use.
title: Genome-wide interaction study implicates VGLL2 and alcohol exposure and PRL and smoking in orofacial cleft risk

finding: The SNP rs117083's minor allele G was associated with an alarming 2.73 times higher odds of NSCL/P for individuals with periconceptional alcohol exposure and a 35% reduction in odds for those without. These findings underscored the impactful role of genetic variants in environmental interactions.
title: Genome-wide interaction study implicates VGLL2 and alcohol exposure and PRL and smoking in orofacial cleft risk

finding: This intronic RSPO3 variant had a top association (P = 3.2 x 10^-32) with GFATadjBMI and an inverse relation to VATadjBMI, indicating shifts in fat distribution.
title: Inherited basis of visceral, abdominal subcutaneous and gluteofemoral fat depots

finding: This SNP was identified as associated with the response to pertussis toxin (PT), with a beta value of 0.33 and a P-value of 1.9×10^-27, suggesting its significance in modulating antibody responses in vaccinated infants.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: This SNP showed strong association with diphtheria toxin (DT) response, characterized by a beta of -0.56 and P-value of 1.5×10^-26, indicating it plays a critical role in immunogenicity after vaccination.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: Identified as influential in response to hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), this SNP had a beta of 0.35 and a P-value of 9.0×10^-13, reflecting its importance in vaccine-induced antibody levels.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: This SNP was associated with the filamentous haemagglutinin (FHA) response, showing a beta of -0.30 and a P-value of 9.8×10^-16, highlighting its relevance to the immune response to this vaccine component.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: Linked to the response to pertactin (PRN), this SNP demonstrated an association with a beta of 0.37 and a P-value of 4.2×10^-23, emphasizing its role in modulating vaccine effectiveness.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: This variant was associated with reduced diphtheria antibody levels, showing an effect on expression of the HLA-DRB1 gene, with a P-value of 1.6×10^-4 indicating its significant impact on the immunogenic response.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: This SNP was significantly correlated with decreased antibody response to pertussis toxin (PT), with a P-value of 6.6×10^-25, and reduced expression of HLA-DRB1, reinforcing its role in antibody response variance.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: This SNP was confirmed to have a strong effect on HLA-C expression in African populations, consistent with previous findings, and was reported with a P-value of 1.14×10^-12.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: The SNP rs9265969 was newly associated with OCD at the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) region on chromosome 6, close to the HLA-B gene. This finding implicates immune system factors in OCD, linking it with multiple psychiatric disorders.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies new loci associated with OCD

finding: The SNP rs699947 was identified in the promotor region of the VEGF gene. The research conducted by Van Den Bossche et al. in 2019 suggested a significant role of this SNP in mediating hippocampal volume changes following electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). The findings indicated that variations at this locus could influence neuroplasticity responses associated with ECT and, consequently, relate to treatment outcomes in depressive episodes.
title: Analyzing Fractal Dimension in Electroconvulsive Therapy: Unraveling Complexity in Structural and Functional Neuroimaging

finding: The rs766406 variant in the 6p22.2 region was associated with the mean diffusivity (MD) of the inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus, indicating its relevance to sleep-related DTI parameters.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: rs34556183 in the 6p22.1 locus was associated with the mean diffusivity (MD) of the superior corona radiata and acted as a brain eQTL, linking genetic architecture to sleep duration.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: In the Japanese population, the rs2105898T variant was significantly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) after correction for multiple comparisons, with an FDR Q value of 0.0067. This variant has been previously associated with SLE in European populations, supporting its role in the risk of developing the disease.
title: Genetic dissection of HLA-DRB1*15:01 and XL9 region variants in Japanese patients with systemic lupus erythematosus: Primary role for HLA-DRB1*15:01

finding: The rs9271593C variant was also found to be significantly associated with SLE in the Japanese population, with an FDR Q value of 0.037. Similar to rs2105898, this variant had been previously reported in association with SLE in European populations, reinforcing its significance.
title: Genetic dissection of HLA-DRB1*15:01 and XL9 region variants in Japanese patients with systemic lupus erythematosus: Primary role for HLA-DRB1*15:01

finding: The index variant rs9380529 at locus 6p21.31 was found in the 95% credible set for Forced Vital Capacity (FVC). Its negative beta coefficient indicated a decreasing effect on vital capacity, which correlated with a higher risk of IPF.
title: Leveraging global multi-ancestry meta-analysis in the study of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis genetics

finding: Rs28435135 was implicated in linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs9380529 regarding FVC, and was found to have an LD value of r^2 = 0.28.
title: Leveraging global multi-ancestry meta-analysis in the study of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis genetics

finding: Variant rs6931277 was significantly associated with Type 1 Diabetes (T1D), as well as rheumatoid arthritis with rheumatoid factor (RA) and other rheumatoid arthritis in the PheWAS. This SNP replicated in both the UK Biobank (UKBB) and the eMERGE Network, highlighting its role in immune-related disorders. Furthermore, it had eQTLs indicating significant changes in gene expression in brain tissues relevant to Alzheimer's Disease (AD), specifically impacting genes like HLA-DQA2, HLA-DRB1, and HLA-DRB6.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: Variant rs9272561 was significantly associated with intestinal malabsorption (K90) and ulcerative colitis (K51) in the UKBB. It was part of a group of variants demonstrating a connection between gut disorders and AD, reinforcing the hypothesis of a gut-brain axis influence on AD outcomes.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: Variant rs9268877 was significantly associated with intestinal malabsorption and ulcerative colitis, replicating findings from the UKBB dataset. This association implied its potential role in gastrointestinal health in patients with Alzheimer's.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: Variant rs9271058 was found to be significantly associated with intestinal malabsorption and ulcerative colitis. Its associations reinforced the idea of overlapping pathways between immune responses and AD.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: Variant rs9271192 showed significant associations with intestinal malabsorption and ulcerative colitis in the UKBB, suggesting its involvement in immune-related pathways that could impact AD pathology.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: Variant rs2516049 was significantly associated with ulcerative colitis and rheumatoid arthritis, indicating its potential link between autoimmune disorders and AD. It replicated across both UKBB and eMERGE datasets.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: Variant rs2975033 was significantly associated with disorders of metabolic metabolism. This association, found within the MHC region, suggested its involvement in metabolic pathways related to AD.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: Variant rs536810 replicated significant associations with rheumatoid arthritis, specifically RA with rheumatoid factor, in both cohorts. This variant's influence on immune gene expression in brain tissues was notable in the context of AD.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: The SNP rs1799971 in OPRM1 was newly confirmed as a variant associated with PAU, consistent with its previously noted associations with opioid use disorder (OUD), emphasizing its potential role in addictive behaviors.
title: Multi-ancestry study of the genetics of problematic alcohol use in >1 million individuals

finding: The SNP rs456261 was located intronic to the PFDN6 gene on chromosome 6p21.32. It achieved a genome-wide significant association with CAP (p=4.00×10⁻²⁸), suggesting a potential role in susceptibility to infectious diseases.
title: A genome-wide association study of adults with community-acquired pneumonia

finding: rs2076775, also positioned on chromosome 6p21.32 and intronic to SYNGAP1, demonstrated a significant association with CAP (p=7.26×10⁻¹⁰). This signifies its relevance in the context of pneumonia susceptibility.
title: A genome-wide association study of adults with community-acquired pneumonia

finding: Located at chromosome 6p21.32, the SNP rs213226 was identified as intergenic to RING1 and HCG25, displaying a significant association with CAP (p=8.64×10⁻⁹). Its involvement adds to the understanding of genetic susceptibility.
title: A genome-wide association study of adults with community-acquired pneumonia

finding: The SNP rs1799971 was the lead SNP in the genome-wide association studies (GWAS) for opioid use disorder (OUD). It was significantly associated with OUD in European Americans (EAs) only, with a highly significant p-value of 6.78 x 10^{-10}. This variant is noted as a non-synonymous coding variant located in the gene OPRM1, which encodes the mu-opioid receptor, a key receptor in the neurobiology of opioid actions.
title: Cross-ancestry meta-analysis of opioid use disorder uncovers novel loci with predominant effects on brain

finding: The missense variant rs10305492 in the GLP1R gene displayed a significant RG-lowering effect, linking it to GLP-1R function and confirming the gene's role as a target in diabetes treatment.
title: Random glucose GWAS in 493,036 individuals provides insights into diabetes pathophysiology, complications and treatment stratification

finding: The SNP rs6923761 (G168S) exhibited function in GLP-1R coupled signalling pathways, although it had a smaller RG-lowering effect compared to rs10305492, indicating variability in GLP-1R responses to agonists.
title: Random glucose GWAS in 493,036 individuals provides insights into diabetes pathophysiology, complications and treatment stratification

finding: The variant rs146868158 (R421W) showed a reduced response to GLP-1R agonists while maintaining normal endocytosis, suggesting biased agonism, and also highlighted its RG effects.
title: Random glucose GWAS in 493,036 individuals provides insights into diabetes pathophysiology, complications and treatment stratification

finding: Identified as a GWS variant for OUD, this SNP located in the OPRM1 gene was confirmed in both ancestry-specific and cross-ancestry analyses, underscoring its established significance in opioid use disorder.
title: Genome-wide association study and multi-trait analysis of opioid use disorder identifies novel associations in 639,709 individuals of European and African ancestry

finding: This variant, also located in the OPRM1 gene, was associated with OUD as a GWS finding in the EUR analysis, though it was shown to be in a low linkage disequilibrium with rs1799971.
title: Genome-wide association study and multi-trait analysis of opioid use disorder identifies novel associations in 639,709 individuals of European and African ancestry

finding: This intronic variant of the OPRM1 gene was identified in the cross-ancestry analysis as a GWS association for OUD, supporting its relevance in opioid addiction risk.
title: Genome-wide association study and multi-trait analysis of opioid use disorder identifies novel associations in 639,709 individuals of European and African ancestry

finding: The SNP rs116113866 was initially associated with a null association between chronic HBV infection and cervical cancer, showing an odds ratio of 1.04 (95% CI = 0.98-1.10, P-value = 0.209). After conducting an MR-PRESSO analysis, it was found causally associated with cervical cancer, with an increased odds ratio of 1.30 (95% CI = 1.12-1.51, P-value = 0.0263).
