title: Multitrait Genome-Wide Analysis in the UK Biobank Reveals Novel and Distinct Variants Influencing Cardiovascular Traits in Africans and Europeans

finding: SNP rs2267667 was similarly noted for its high frequency in the EUR population, establishing it as a positive and original finding linked to cardiovascular traits.
title: Multitrait Genome-Wide Analysis in the UK Biobank Reveals Novel and Distinct Variants Influencing Cardiovascular Traits in Africans and Europeans

finding: SNP rs7751481 showed significant associations within the EUR population in relation to cardiovascular traits, affirming its positive and original finding.
title: Multitrait Genome-Wide Analysis in the UK Biobank Reveals Novel and Distinct Variants Influencing Cardiovascular Traits in Africans and Europeans

finding: In the analysis of HIV-1 subtype B data from the Swiss HIV Cohort Study, SNP rs9265880 showed a significant increase in association strength when using estimates for the non-pathogen part of the trait for spVL. The p-value for this SNP improved from 3.5 × 10^{-7} to 7.7 × 10^{-9}, indicating a stronger association in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) region. This finding was consistent with the top-associated SNPs identified in prior studies, reinforcing the relevance of this variant in understanding host genetic factors influencing spVL.
title: A phylogeny-aware GWAS framework to correct for heritable pathogen effects on infectious disease traits

finding: The SNP rs4443534 was associated with altered type 2 diabetes risk. This finding indicated that variants in the NUS1 gene, which rs4443534 represents, could influence the susceptibility to developing type 2 diabetes, thereby underscoring its potential role as a biomarker in diabetes progression.
title: Novel biomarkers for glycaemic deterioration in type 2 diabetes: an IMI RHAPSODY study

finding: The SNP rs9273363 was located in chromosome 6 in the intergenic region spanning HLA-DQA1 and HLA-DQB1, displaying a significant association with Long COVID (OR=1.06, p=3.79x10^-11). Effect sizes were consistent across European, Latinx, and African-American ancestries.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS of Long COVID identifies immune-related loci and etiological links to chronic fatigue syndrome, fibromyalgia and depression

finding: An indel variant rs9281499 in the intergenic region of MICA and MICB displayed significant association with Long COVID (OR=0.91, p=1.18x10^-09), with evidence of linkage to multiple pQTL for MICB protein in blood plasma.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS of Long COVID identifies immune-related loci and etiological links to chronic fatigue syndrome, fibromyalgia and depression

finding: The genetic variant rs1265081 in the CCHCR1 gene was shown to be associated with radiotherapy-induced oral mucositis (OM) in head and neck cancer patients. CCHCR1 is involved in regulating cellular processes such as keratinocyte proliferation and differentiation and impacts EGFR pathways.
title: Systematic Review of Genetic Polymorphisms Associated with Acute Pain and Relevant Acute Toxicities Induced by Radiotherapy for Head and Neck Cancer

finding: Variant rs1799964 was identified as a predictive factor for acute toxicities in Chinese rectal cancer patients treated with chemoradiotherapy, implicating its role in inflammation pathways.
title: Systematic Review of Genetic Polymorphisms Associated with Acute Pain and Relevant Acute Toxicities Induced by Radiotherapy for Head and Neck Cancer

finding: The SNP rs67714619, situated near PTPRK, had a P-value of 2.4×10^-8 in the Hispanic population, with an odds ratio of 1.34, indicative of a potential risk-increasing effect.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide meta-analysis of 56,241 individuals identifies LRRC4C, LHX5-AS1 and nominates ancestry-specific loci PTPRK, GRB14, and KIAA0825 as novel risk loci for Alzheimer’s disease: the Alzheimer’s Disease Genetics Consortium

finding: The SNP rs13206045 was found at the SYNE1 locus located at 6q25.1, with a significant P-value of 3.20x10-4, indicating its relevance in endometriosis research.
title: Enhancing Genetic Association Power in Endometriosis through Unsupervised Clustering of Clinical Subtypes Identified from Electronic Health Records

finding: SNP rs2516396 was identified as a positive original finding which colocalized with cg11554650 (PPP1R18), a CpG associated with type 2 diabetes, at a PPFC of 0.98. This link provided a strong indication that methylation at this CpG could have implications for type 2 diabetes risk.
title: Elucidating the genetic architecture of DNA methylation to identify promising molecular mechanisms of disease

finding: Identified among the 637 significant associations and intersected with 12 associations from a landmark study, indicating a significant connection to autism.
title: Exploring autism and autism co-occurring condition associations to elucidate multivariate genetic mechanisms and insights

finding: The SNP rs9347480 was positively associated with increased prostate cancer risk, with a statistical significance of P = 1.41 × 10^-07. The risk allele C of this SNP was also linked to decreased protein expression of human plasminogen (PLG), with a P-value of 4.57 × 10^-33. Additionally, the analysis indicated decreased gene expression of PLG in prostate tumor samples compared to normal samples, which was significant with a P-value of 0.038. These findings suggested that PLG might function as a potential tumor suppressor in the context of prostate cancer.
title: Large-scale integration of omics and electronic health records to identify potential risk protein biomarkers and therapeutic drugs for cancer prevention and intervention

finding: The SNP rs104894002 was found to be a pLOF variant causing a stop gain (p.Q33S) in exon 2 of TREM2, with a significant association in the replication set (P=8.86×10−6). This variant had been previously identified in Alzheimer's disease cases, reinforcing its potential role in the disease.
title: Rare Variant Aggregation in 148,508 Exomes Identifies Genes Associated with Proxy Alzheimer’s disease/Dementia

finding: The SNP rs3132386 showed a primary signal in schizophrenia (SCZ) studies. It had a secondary signal related to the same context through its connection to the mQTL-CpG cg15026241, further supporting causal interpretations.
title: Potentially causal associations between placental DNA methylation and schizophrenia and other neuropsychiatric disorders

finding: The SNP rs16897420 correlated significantly in SCZ analyses and was associated with the same mQTL site as rs3132386. The findings indicated a pleiotropic effect involving DNA methylation patterns in the placenta.
title: Potentially causal associations between placental DNA methylation and schizophrenia and other neuropsychiatric disorders

finding: The rs17754910 SNP was identified as a significant marker for early-onset breast cancer (EOBC), exceeding the genome-wide significance threshold with a p value of 4.73 x 10^-9. This finding was related to a haplotype that includes multiple markers in a region enriched with regulatory elements, specifically associated with the non-coding RNA LINC02527, which has been linked to alternating methylation patterns in various cancers, including breast cancer.
title: Retrospective analysis of The Two Sister Study using haplotype-based association testing to identify loci associated with early-onset breast cancer

finding: The SNP rs1800562, located in the HFE gene, was associated with iron absorption and metabolism. In this study, it contributed to a risk score that indicated its potential impact on serum iron levels, particularly among those consuming alcohol, suggesting a link to brain iron accumulation with alcohol intake.
title: Impact of moderate alcohol consumption on brain iron and cognition: observational and genetic analyses

finding: Similar to rs1800562, the SNP rs1799945, also within the HFE gene, was established as a genetic factor influencing iron absorption. The research integrated this SNP into the risk score for serum iron levels, which elucidated its role in the associations observed with alcohol consumption and iron accumulation in the brain.
title: Impact of moderate alcohol consumption on brain iron and cognition: observational and genetic analyses

finding: The SNP rs12190287 located in TCF21 was found in the combined approach for coronary atherosclerosis and had earlier associations with the risk of coronary artery disease as reported in previous studies.
title: Genetic association studies using disease liabilities from deep neural networks

finding: The SNP rs10455872 in LPA was identified to be associated with hypercholesterolemia using the CC-liability method and was reported as significant in other GWAS within the UK Biobank.
title: Genetic association studies using disease liabilities from deep neural networks

finding: The -460T/C polymorphism showed significant risk for schizophrenia, particularly prevalent among undifferentiated forms of the disorder. Additionally, it was found that there was an impact on patients' symptomatology, linking it to schizophrenia's clinical characteristics.
title: Association of VEGF and KDR polymorphisms with the development of schizophrenia

finding: The +936C/T polymorphism was associated with an increased risk of schizophrenia. The study showed clear evidence of a relationship between this variant and the disorder, indicating its importance in the disorder's pathology.
title: Association of VEGF and KDR polymorphisms with the development of schizophrenia

finding: The variant p.A125V in TNFAIP3 was associated with familial autoinflammatory, Behcet-like syndrome (OMIM: 616744) and was found to be significantly high in the Sub-Saharan African subpopulation of Qatar with an allele frequency (AF) of 1.6% compared to 0.16% in gnomAD V2.
title: Genetic landscape of rare autoinflammatory disease variants in Qatar and Middle Eastern populations through the integration of whole-genome and exome datasets

finding: The SNP rs4712314 was suggestively significant in the context of PSP with a p-value of 2.37 × 10^-7 pointing towards the role of KIF13A.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: The SNP rs367364 showed a suggestive association with PSP, presenting a p-value of 7.07 × 10^-7, significant within the MHC region.
title: Whole-Genome Sequencing Analysis Reveals New Susceptibility Loci and Structural Variants Associated with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy

finding: The SNP rs35261542 was identified as significantly associated with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). It was replicated alongside other variants in the context of high-risk traits for GDM.
title: Genetic studies of gestational diabetes mellitus in 21,813 Chinese women

finding: The association of SNP rs4712530 with GDM risk was confirmed through conditional and joint (COJO) association analysis, indicating its role in the genetic landscape of GDM.
title: Genetic studies of gestational diabetes mellitus in 21,813 Chinese women

finding: The DSP gene variant rs2076295 exhibited an odds ratio (OR) of 1.31 (95% CI: 1.00-1.63; p < 0.05), suggesting it is associated with elevated IPF risk. It influenced desmoplakin expression, which is vital for maintaining epithelial integrity, implying a key role in lung fibrosis mechanisms.
title: Genetic landscape of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: A systematic review, meta-analysis and epidemiological evidence of case-control studies

finding: This SNP was found to be significantly associated with disorders of iron metabolism, with an exceptionally strong P-value of 1×10^-178, highlighting its critical role in these metabolic processes.
title: Leveraging large-scale multi-omics to identify therapeutic targets from genome-wide association studies

finding: For SNP rs557074, while it exhibited no significant correlation with peak-gene expression in healthy oligodendrocytes, it was found to be associated with gene expressions in disease-associated oligodendrocytes, highlighting its potential role in the pathophysiology of Parkinson's disease.
title: Single-nuclei paired multiomic analysis of young, aged, and Parkinson’s disease human midbrain reveals age- and disease-associated glial changes and their contribution to Parkinson’s disease

finding: The variant rs9267499, located in the HSPA1A gene, was identified as having a strong association with detectable mosaic loss of the X chromosome (mLOX), especially driven by a higher frequency of the risk allele in the Finnish population compared to other ancestries.
title: Population analyses of mosaic X chromosome loss identify genetic drivers and widespread signatures of cellular selection

finding: This SNPin the CENPQ gene was associated with mLOX susceptibility where an odds ratio (OR) of 0.96 indicated a protective effect against mLOX, while having no significant effect on mLOY.
title: Population analyses of mosaic X chromosome loss identify genetic drivers and widespread signatures of cellular selection

finding: The rs9398805 variant was linked to mLOX susceptibility and identified within the CENPW gene. This SNP showed connections to various autoimmune diseases, corroborating mLOX's relations to autoimmunity.
title: Population analyses of mosaic X chromosome loss identify genetic drivers and widespread signatures of cellular selection

finding: In this study, rs533280354 was identified as a novel East Asian ancestry-specific risk variant in the 5' UTR of the FKBP5 gene. This variant disrupted the binding of the transcription factor KLF15, leading to decreased transcription of FKBP5, which is implicated in high myopia (HM). The risk allele frequency was found to be significantly higher in East Asian populations compared to European ones, indicating its localized relevance.
title: Sequencing of 19,219 exomes identifies a low-frequency variant in FKBP5 promoter predisposing to high myopia in a Han Chinese population

finding: The SNP rs35985881 was part of a significant finding where it and another variant (rs35730227) were located in the intron region of RIPOR2. These variants were detected in cases of high myopia (HM), with a P-value of 2.26 × 10^-9, indicating their association with the condition.
title: Sequencing of 19,219 exomes identifies a low-frequency variant in FKBP5 promoter predisposing to high myopia in a Han Chinese population

finding: Similar to rs35985881, rs35730227 showed significant association with high myopia (HM) as it was identified in the intronic region of RIPOR2. Both variants were detected with a P-value of 2.26 × 10^-9, highlighting their importance in the genetic architecture of HM.
title: Sequencing of 19,219 exomes identifies a low-frequency variant in FKBP5 promoter predisposing to high myopia in a Han Chinese population

finding: The SNP rs146918648 was found to be associated with the female PTS factor 1 (PTS-f1). It was positionally mapped to an intronic region of the SCAND3 gene, which had been previously linked to well-being, depressive symptoms, and positive affect. The strong association was evidenced by a beta value of -0.072 and a p-value of 6.73×10^-9, indicating its significance in the context of PTSD symptoms in females.
title: Sex-stratified genomic structural equation models of posttraumatic stress inform PTSD etiology

finding: The SNP rs9357455, located upstream of the PHACTR1 gene, showed an association with early-onset AMI (odds ratio = 0.666, p-value = 9.73 × 10^-6). This locus is thought to regulate inflammation processes in AMI, impacting oxidative stress and endothelial cell interactions.
title: Genome-wide analyses of early-onset acute myocardial infarction identify 29 novel loci by whole genome sequencing

finding: The rs150899739 variant was associated with an increased risk of HPC in Mixed ancestry, showcasing strong odds ratio effects.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The rs28360051 variant near PSORS1C3 was associated with increased risk of HNSCC, particularly driven by HPV(+ )OPC.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: Variant rs1536036 in ITPR3 was found to protect against overall HNSCC, particularly in admixed populations.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The rs4143334 variant in ZDHHC20P2 was associated with increased risk of HPV(+) OPC, presenting an odds ratio of 1.89 (95% CI: 1.51, 2.35, p_meta=1.91×10^-8).
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The rs2523679 variant provided a cross ancestral equivalent of HLA-B*15:01, tagging previously identified European-specific variants.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The rs1131212 variant, which caused an amino acid change in HLA-B, demonstrated increased risk for HPV(-) OPC with an odds ratio of 1.33 (95% CI: 1.19, 1.49, p_meta=5.33×10^-7).
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: This known variant was highlighted for its strong association with HPV(-) OPC risk.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The lead SNP for OC cancer was correlated with a novel risk haplotype of DRB1*15:01-DQA1*01:02-DQB1*06:02, showing equivalency in effect on risk.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: This novel variant was discovered to have impactful significance for oral cavity cancers, particularly in European populations.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: The OC-specific validated variant rs4990036 was additionally associated with varicella zoster, illuminating its potential role in non-HPV-related factors in cancer risk.
title: Cross-ancestral GWAS identifies 29 novel variants across Head and Neck Cancer subsites

finding: An association was found between rs28414666 and pernicious anemia, corresponding to the HLA-DQB1 gene, which is a critical player in autoimmune disease susceptibility.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies five risk loci for pernicious anemia and implicates the role of HLA-DR15 haplotype

finding: The SNP rs76826738, located in an intron of the SMOC2 gene, was found to have genome-wide significance (p = 2.95 x10^-8) in the comparison between T.b. gambiense cases and controls. This finding highlighted the potential role of SMOC2 in the susceptibility to human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) and indicated that it warranted further functional investigation due to its involvement in endothelial cell growth and differentiation, potentially impacting permeability relevant to parasite invasion.
title: A Genome-Wide Association Study Reveals Novel Genetic Markers Associated with Human African Trypanosomiasis

finding: The SNP rs17843689 was associated with the structure observed in the first two principal components (PCA) of the African super-population data from the 1000 Genomes Project. The analysis revealed that the SNP's allele count (0, 1, or 2 for the effect allele) influenced the location of samples within PCA space, indicating its significance in distinguishing genetic variance within this super-population.
title: Simulating genetic risk scores from summary statistics with an application to type 1 diabetes

finding: The rs117160741 SNP was identified as novel and associated with SASH1, and it showed an interaction with the APOE SNP, rs429358, which suggested its potential involvement in AD pathology.
title: Novel Alzheimer’s disease genes and epistasis identified using machine learning GWAS platform

finding: The rs9918382 SNP in the SASH1 gene was involved in a triplet interaction with the pathogenic SNP rs429358 (APOE) and rs7552961 (ACOT11), implying a protective effect against AD that could be reversed under certain genotype combinations.
title: Novel Alzheimer’s disease genes and epistasis identified using machine learning GWAS platform

finding: The SNP rs9268848 was identified as a colocalized event for the gene HLA-DQA1 and HLA-DQB1, contributing to the phenotypic variation of neutrophil percentage (NEUT%). This finding linked genetic variations to immune response traits.
title: Genetic determinants of gene expression noise and its role in complex trait variation

finding: The SNP rs362538 was associated with multiple sclerosis (MS) as a colocalized event with the enQTLs of HLA-A in CD4 cells, where its G allele correlated with increased MS risk while being linked to attenuated noise in gene expression.
title: Genetic determinants of gene expression noise and its role in complex trait variation

finding: SNP rs35984974 was an intergenic variant near ZNF184 that was associated with all four substance use traits.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: SNP rs1799971 was located in the OPRM1 gene and was previously found to be GWS in prior OUD GWAS. It was identified as a lead variant in the MTAG-OUD analysis.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: SNP rs112126124 was an intergenic variant near TMEM170B identified as a novel locus associated with multiple substance use traits.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: SNP rs411136, an exonic variant in SYNGAP1, identified as novel in the AUD analysis.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: SNP rs12526369 was an intergenic variant near TMEM170B identified as novel for smoking trait associations.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS (MTAG) of Substance Use Traits Identifies Novel Genetic Loci and Phenomic Associations

finding: The study identified rs9375442 as a lead SNP showing genome-wide significant effects in the Group 3 GWAS. This intronic variant on chromosome 6, located in the CENPW gene, was associated with increased expression of CENPW, which contributed to decreased cortical volume and cognitive function by potentially altering neurogenesis or increasing apoptosis. It was confirmed that this SNP was linked to neurocognitive performance, with further findings indicating a higher CENPW score in adolescents from Group 3 compared to Groups 1 and 2, and positive correlations between this score and improvements in neurocognition and conduct problems.
title: Structural neurodevelopment at the individual level - a life-course investigation using ABCD, IMAGEN and UK Biobank data

finding: The rs75932628 variant, known as R47H, was associated with the greatest relative risk for Alzheimer's disease (AD), approximately 3.9 times that of homozygous common alleles. Carriers of this variant showed earlier symptoms of AD, experienced faster cognitive decline, and exhibited increased levels of hyperphosphorylated tau in cerebrospinal fluid.
title: Mechanisms contributing to differential genetic risks for TREM2 R47H and R62H variants in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The rs143332484 variant, referred to as R62H, was found to be more prevalent with a minor allele frequency of 0.97%. This variant conferred a smaller risk for Alzheimer's disease, approximately 1.4 times that of homozygous common alleles, indicating a reduced effect on disease risk compared to the R47H variant.
title: Mechanisms contributing to differential genetic risks for TREM2 R47H and R62H variants in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs2758339 was identified in a study that associated it with the risk of heroin dependency and the expression levels of SOD2. This finding highlighted the potential influence of genetic polymorphisms on opioid use disorders, which may relate to the broader context of OUD as discussed in the abstract.
title: Profiling Neuronal Methylome and Hydroxymethylome of Opioid Use Disorder in the Human Orbitofrontal Cortex

finding: The SNP rs5746136 was also found to be associated with the risk of heroin dependency and the expression levels of SOD2. This link suggested a genetic contribution to opioid use disorders similar to the findings presented in the abstract regarding the developmental mechanisms underlying OUD.
title: Profiling Neuronal Methylome and Hydroxymethylome of Opioid Use Disorder in the Human Orbitofrontal Cortex

finding: The SNP rs28718232 was notably significant for European ancestry analysis related to cervical cancer.
title: GWAS meta-analysis and gene expression data link reproductive tract development, immune response and cellular proliferation/apoptosis with cervical cancer and clarify overlap with other cervical phenotypes

finding: The missense variant rs76863441 was identified as a cis-pQTL for PLA2G7. This variant had a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.06 in East Asians, while falling below 0.001 in other populations. PLA2G7 is known to be related to inflammation, cardiovascular disease (CVD), and lifespan, highlighting its relevance to these health issues. The finding was consistent across both OLINK and SomaScan platforms, indicating its potential importance for future research on related traits.
title: Comparative studies of genetic and phenotypic associations for 2,168 plasma proteins measured by two affinity-based platforms in 4,000 Chinese adults

finding: The SNP rs143821594 was identified as an outlier during the analysis, but its exclusion did not significantly alter the causal association found between SLE and CHF. The analysis showed that genetic susceptibility to SLE, including this SNP, was associated with an increased risk of CHF, with an odds ratio of 1.032 (95% CI 1.004–1.061, P=0.023).
title: The potential causal association of systemic lupus erythematosus with congestive heart failure in the East Asian population: A two-sample Mendelian randomization study

finding: The SNP rs1210063 was located on chromosome 6 and mapped to the gene PREP. The effect allele G was associated with increased susceptibility to EBV, evidenced by a p-value of 4.01×10^-9 in the GWAS.
title: Unpicking the Gordian knot: Mendelian randomization to elucidate the risk factors for infectious diseases, using EBV as a model pathogen

finding: The removal of variant rs1633106 resulted in a statistically significant IVW effect estimate demonstrating a connection between increased sleep duration and reduced rate of motor progression in Parkinson's disease, showcasing its role in ameliorating motor decline.
title: Relationship between sleep and progression of Parkinson’s disease – A Mendelian randomization study

finding: This SNP, rs660895 in the HLA-DRB1 gene, correlated with elevated IgA serum levels and proteinuria in patients, suggesting its involvement in IgAN.
title: Candidate genes for IgA nephropathy in pediatric patients: exome-wide association study

finding: The variant rs1799945 in HFE showed the strongest association with hepatic iron content (HIC) in men. This SNP led to hepatic iron overload due to decreased hepcidin levels and was associated with increased ferritin and transferrin levels.
title: Distribution and associated factors of hepatic iron – a population-based imaging study

finding: The variant rs1800562 in HFE demonstrated the strongest association with hepatic iron content (HIC) in women. Similar to rs1799945, this SNP contributed to hepatic iron overload due to decreased hepcidin levels, and was also associated with elevated ferritin and transferrin.
title: Distribution and associated factors of hepatic iron – a population-based imaging study

finding: This SNP featured significant associations predominantly within blood measures, size and impedance measures, and autoimmune phenotypes found in the UK Biobank.
title: Exome sequencing of 628,388 individuals identifies common and rare variant associations with clonal hematopoiesis phenotypes

finding: It exhibited significant associations across various health traits, especially related to blood measures according to the analysis conducted.
title: Exome sequencing of 628,388 individuals identifies common and rare variant associations with clonal hematopoiesis phenotypes

finding: The study found that rs2904602, located in the TNF-beta gene, exhibited strong colocalization with idiopathic membranous nephropathy (IMN) as indicated by a high Posterior Probability of Hypothesis 4 (PPH4) of 0.88. This finding suggested that rs2904602 shared the same causal variant with IMN, highlighting its potential significance in understanding the genetic predisposition to IMN.
title: Circulating inflammatory proteins may be potential drug targets for Idiopathic Membranous Nephropathy: proteome-wide Mendelian Randomization and colocalization analysis

finding: The SNP rs6923761, also known as Gly168Ser in the GLP-1R gene, was significantly associated with a reduction in HbA1c levels following GLP-1RA treatment. Each Serine allele was associated with a decrease of 0.9 mmol/mol in HbA1c (p=6.0×10^-05). This finding provided novel insights into how genetic variation influences the efficacy of GLP-1RA in type 2 diabetes treatment.
title: Pharmacogenomics of GLP-1 Receptor Agonists: A genome wide analysis of observational data and large randomized controlled trials

finding: This SNP was identified as the lead variant for HLA-DQA1 expression in myeloid cells, showing a notable association (P = 8.04 × 10^-127). A higher dosage of the G allele correlated with increased HLA-DQA1 expression, and it was frequently in phase with the HLA-DQA1*03:01 allele, which is linked to type 1 diabetes and celiac disease.
title: Mapping the dynamic genetic regulatory architecture of HLA genes at single-cell resolution

finding: This secondary independent variant, located approximately 1.4 kb upstream of HLA-DQA1, was shown to be significantly associated with HLA-DQA1 expression in myeloid cells (P = 3.06 × 10^-58) after conditioning on the effect of rs3104413.
title: Mapping the dynamic genetic regulatory architecture of HLA genes at single-cell resolution

finding: This SNP was the lead eQTL for HLA-DRB1 in B cells, exhibiting a strong effect size (β = 0.7, P = 1.08 × 10^-128), which was approximately three-fold weaker in myeloid cells and absent in T cells.
title: Mapping the dynamic genetic regulatory architecture of HLA genes at single-cell resolution

finding: This SNP showed much stronger regulatory effects in B cells compared to myeloid and T cells (β = 0.43 in B cells vs. 0.04 in myeloid and 0.08 in T cells), indicating its specific influence on HLA-DPA1 expression.
title: Mapping the dynamic genetic regulatory architecture of HLA genes at single-cell resolution

finding: This variant exhibited similar strong regulatory effects in B cells for HLA-DPB1, showing β = 0.55 versus 0.07 and 0.12 in myeloid and T cells, respectively, highlighting its role in B cell eQTL dynamics.
title: Mapping the dynamic genetic regulatory architecture of HLA genes at single-cell resolution

finding: This SNP was identified as the lead eQTL for HLA-DQA1 in T cells, with the strongest effects observed in several T cell states such as gamma-delta and cytotoxic CD8+ T cells, suggesting dynamic regulation of HLA-DQA1 during immune activation.
title: Mapping the dynamic genetic regulatory architecture of HLA genes at single-cell resolution

finding: This SNP acted as a dynamic eQTL for HLA-A in T cells, where its effects were strongest during T cell proliferation, indicating that its regulatory role varies according to cell state.
title: Mapping the dynamic genetic regulatory architecture of HLA genes at single-cell resolution

finding: This SNP served as an eQTL for HLA-DQA1 in B cells, contributing to state-dependent expression patterns observed with interaction P < 2 × 10^-9 in both Synovium and PBMC-blood.
title: Mapping the dynamic genetic regulatory architecture of HLA genes at single-cell resolution

finding: This SNP was part of the credible set with a high pattern of pairwise linkage disequilibrium, highlighting its possible impact on loss of ambulation in DMD patients.
title: A genome-wide association analysis of loss of ambulation in dystrophinopathy patients suggests multiple candidate modifiers of disease severity

finding: The rs2501968 variant in the CENPQ/MUT locus was confirmed to be associated with ischemic stroke, with replication results supporting the original discovery. It demonstrated strong evidence of being an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for both the CENPQ and MUT genes, particularly in arterial tissues.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis identifies 2 novel loci associated with ischemic stroke and reveals heterogeneity of effects between sexes and ancestries

finding: The SNP rs1247295 in the MAP3K4 locus interacted with sex and was associated with lipoprotein levels, qualifying it as an important vQTL.
title: Hypothesis-free detection of gene-interaction effects on biomarker concentration in UK Biobank using variance prioritisation

finding: The SNP rs2760985, which tags the HLA-DRB1 gene, showed the most pronounced association with PMR, although it was confirmed as consistent with prior reports. It was noted for statistical evidence of heterogeneity across the FinnGen and UK Biobank cohorts.
title: Modifiable risk factors and inflammation-related proteins in polymyalgia rheumatica: genome-wide meta-analysis and Mendelian randomisation

finding: The SNP rs9262120 associated with TUBB in lung cancer displayed significant evidence of affecting gene expression, corroborated through functional assays.
title: Large-scale alternative polyadenylation (APA)-wide association studies to identify putative susceptibility genes in human common cancers

finding: The SNP rs142516820 was found to correlate strongly with eGFR levels. This correlation was particularly significant in the context of its association with the TINAG gene, which displayed a strong relationship with hyperglycemia in the diabetic kidney disease (DKD) setting. The study highlighted the genetic variant's role in kidney function, establishing its relevance as a candidate gene contributing to DKD.
title: Urine extracellular vesicles capture kidney transcriptome and hyperglycemia linked mRNA signatures for type 1 diabetic kidney disease

finding: The variant rs6920364 was positively associated with lung cancer in the meta-analysis. It was identified as a lung eQTL for RNASET2, and as a plasma pQTL associated with higher levels of RNASET2, underscoring its potential contribution to lung cancer pathophysiology.
title: Machine learning-based proteogenomic data modeling identifies circulating plasma biomarkers for early detection of lung cancer

finding: SNP rs7766070, located in the CDKAL1 locus, was identified as one of the seven shared SNPs between type 2 diabetes and PHQ-9, suggesting a significant connection.
title: Bi-directional Mendelian randomization and multi-phenotype GWAS show causality and shared pathophysiology between depression and type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs6296, located in the HTR1B gene, was associated with susceptibility to opioid use disorder. This finding was originally reported in a study by Li et al. in 2022, highlighting its relevance in understanding the genetic factors influencing chronic opioid use.
title: Neuropsychology of chronic back pain managed with long-term opioid use

finding: The SNP rs7752421 was shown to have shared influences with schizophrenia, supported by a posterior probability of PPH4 = 0.952, indicating genetic links between retinal layer thickness and mental health.
title: Eye-brain connections revealed by multimodal retinal and brain imaging genetics in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs3798869 was associated with schizophrenia and was in linkage disequilibrium with the inner nuclear layer (INL) thickness, which could serve as a biomarker for schizophrenia.
title: Eye-brain connections revealed by multimodal retinal and brain imaging genetics in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs17211748, located upstream of HLA-DQB1, showed a significant association with asymptomatic ANA positivity, with a p-value of 1.4×10^-6 and an odds ratio (OR) of 0.82 (95% CI 0.76-0.89). This finding indicated that individuals carrying this variant were less likely to be asymptomatic ANA positive compared to those without the variant in a multi-ancestry analysis.
title: Genetic analysis of asymptomatic antinuclear antibody production

finding: The rs2856448 SNP was associated with Tenascin-X protein levels, also contributing a substantial effect size, showcasing its genetic influence over plasma protein variability.
title: Integrative genetic and immune cell analysis of plasma proteins in healthy donors identifies novel associations involving primary immune deficiency genes

finding: The variant rs116775335 was identified near the POLR1C gene, exhibiting a significant frequency difference between populations, being found at 0.230 in UKB-AFR versus 2.7 x10^-05 in UKB-EUR (p = 3.7 x 10^-60). This indicated that variants near POLR1C may play a role in population-specific disease susceptibility.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: Similarly, rs7743244 near POLR1C also showed a marked frequency difference, with an allele frequency of 0.551 in UKB-AFR compared to 0.061 in UKB-EUR (p = 9.4 x 10^-322), suggesting a potential link to population-specific traits.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: Variants rs1267502 in the JARID2 gene were found to have an allele frequency of 0.252 in UKB-AFR versus 0.985 in UKB-EUR (p = 9.63 x 10^-322), indicating significant implications for population-specific health outcomes.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: The mQTL rs1264313 revealed high relevance as it was associated with multiple biomarkers, indicating its potential impact on metabolic health.
title: Mapping Epigenetic Gene Variant Dynamics: Comparative Analysis of Frequency, Functional Impact and Trait Associations in African and European Populations

finding: This SNP served as a tag for the HLA-DQB1*57 allele and had significant interactions with multiple other risk variants, notably in predicting T1D.
title: Genetic association and machine learning improves discovery and prediction of type 1 diabetes

finding: Marked as a risk variant for T1D, this SNP at position 13 of the HLA-DRB1 gene was annotated with strong linkage to T1D risks and showed interactions with other variants.
title: Genetic association and machine learning improves discovery and prediction of type 1 diabetes

finding: Linked to the protective allele HLA-DQB1*02:01, this variant was integral in underlying the genetic architecture associated with T1D.
title: Genetic association and machine learning improves discovery and prediction of type 1 diabetes

finding: Associated with HLA-DQB1*06:02, this SNP demonstrated a strong connection to the risk profile for T1D.
title: Genetic association and machine learning improves discovery and prediction of type 1 diabetes

finding: Related to the allele HLA-A*24:02, this SNP significantly contributed to the genetic predisposition characterized in T1D.
title: Genetic association and machine learning improves discovery and prediction of type 1 diabetes

finding: Identified as a novel non-coding signal, this variant was implicated in T1D through its mapping in an intergenic region adjacent to HLA-DRB1.
title: Genetic association and machine learning improves discovery and prediction of type 1 diabetes

finding: This novel variant overlaps an accessible chromatin site in CD8+ T cells, indicating its relevance in T1D pathogenesis.
title: Genetic association and machine learning improves discovery and prediction of type 1 diabetes

finding: This SNP demonstrated a strong binding affinity to SOX3, indicating its significant role in T1D genetic risk as a novel non-coding signal.
title: Genetic association and machine learning improves discovery and prediction of type 1 diabetes

finding: Linked to the protective haplotype DRB1*15:01/DQB1*06:02, this SNP contributed to the understanding of HLA-mediated effects in T1D susceptibility.
title: Genetic association and machine learning improves discovery and prediction of type 1 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs6928864 was associated with alterations in transcriptional levels of genes linked to ERBB2-driven breast cancer (BC). This association was crucial in the development of a mouse tumor susceptibility gene signature (mTSGS), which not only provided insights into tumor characteristics but also showed prognostic value in predicting responses to chemotherapy treatments in breast cancer patients. The findings suggested that individuals carrying specific alleles at this locus might experience different tumor phenotypes, contributing significantly to the understanding of ERBB2-related breast cancer progression and treatment outcomes.
title: A susceptibility gene signature for ERBB2-driven mammary tumor development and metastasis in Collaborative Cross mice with human translational value

finding: The rs7766042 SNP was highlighted as a novel regulatory variant of the FOXF2 gene, known to be a risk variant for ischemic stroke and associated with system segregation.
title: Genetic variants link lower segregation of brain networks to higher blood pressure and worse cognition within the general aging population

finding: This SNP, located near the SOX4 gene, was previously reported to be associated with femoral neck BMD and heel BMD, indicating its significant role in bone density traits.
title: SEAD: an augmented reference panel with 22,134 haplotypes boosts the rare variants imputation and GWAS analysis in Asian population

finding: The SNP rs2187668, which represented the HLADQA1 gene, was associated with increased risk of minimal change nephrotic syndrome (MN) in the UK Biobank study. Being homozygous for the high-risk allele T correlated with higher incidences of MN.
title: Membranous Nephropathy in the UK Biobank

finding: The intronic SNP rs4331993 in SYNE1 suggested potential regulatory functions and was included as a likely causal SNP for bipolar disorder.
title: Fine-mapping genomic loci refines bipolar disorder risk genes

finding: The SNP rs10455872 was identified as the most significant genetic instrument for Lp(a), accounting for 63.99% of the total variance explained in Lp(a) concentration. It was confirmed to have causal effects on coronary artery disease (CAD), with an odds ratio of 1.199, indicating that for every 59.632 nmol/L higher Lp(a) instrumented by the LPA genetic risk score, the risk of CAD increased significantly. This effect indicated the importance of Lp(a) in vascular disease beyond merely lipid levels.
title: Evaluating genetically-predicted causal effects of lipoprotein(a) in human diseases: a phenome-wide Mendelian randomization study

finding: The SNP rs140570886 was among the 29 Lp(a) genetic instruments but its individual contribution to the variance explained in Lp(a) levels was not reported in detail. Nevertheless, it contributed to the overall findings that led to complex causal associations of Lp(a) with cardiovascular diseases, reinforcing the role of SNPs at the LPA locus in cardiovascular health.
title: Evaluating genetically-predicted causal effects of lipoprotein(a) in human diseases: a phenome-wide Mendelian randomization study

finding: The rs1547247 SNP in the HBS1L locus was significantly linked to Endoglin plasma levels, having a p-value of 1.98 x 10^-8, and also related to the study of venous thrombosis.
title: Non-canonical regulation of Endoglin by rare and common variants: new molecular and clinical perspectives for Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia and beyond

finding: The A-allele of rs926552 in the GABBR1 gene was associated with a moderate increase in plasma OT levels (β = 0.31, p = 1.58 × 10^-4). This emphasized GABBR1's potential role in OT signaling, particularly in connection to ASD.
title: Genetic and epigenetic signatures associated with plasma oxytocin levels in children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorder

finding: The SNP rs1800562, located in the HFE gene, was associated with haemochromatosis, an inherited disorder characterized by iron overload in the body. The association was highlighted by a significant p-value of 9.16 × 10^-120 and an odds ratio of 102.21 for carriers of the diplotype that included this SNP, indicating a strong link between the recessive alleles of this gene and the disease. Notably, this association was discovered despite the SNP not being directly genotyped in the UK Biobank dataset, emphasizing the efficacy of the ROH-DICE method in identifying such associations even when the actual causal SNP was not available for study.
title: Discovery of runs-of-homozygosity diplotype clusters and their associations with diseases in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs12203592 was significantly associated with Df, with a P-value of 6.59·10^-24. Its association extends to ocular studies, which showed implications in visual acuity and retinal characteristics, while also being connected to the risk of CAD.
title: Decreased retinal vascular complexity is an early biomarker of MI supported by a shared genetic control

finding: This SNP was associated with fractures in individuals older than 18 years, indicating its broader implication in musculoskeletal health, particularly in relation to TBS-associated fractures in the study.
title: Genetic Determinants of Bone Microarchitecture and its Association with Health Outcomes: A Genome-wide Association and Mendelian Randomization Study on Trabecular Bone Score

finding: Recognized as a trans-eSNP influencing EPO expression, its association with hypertension was validated in the analysis, underscoring its importance.
title: An individualized Bayesian method for estimating genomic variants of hypertension

finding: The SNP rs73743401 was located near the IP6K3 and ITPR3 genes, with every additional T allele linked to approximately 22% higher FGF23 concentrations. This association was demonstrated with a significant p-value of 5 x 10^-60, establishing its relevance in FGF23 regulation.
title: Multi-trait Analysis of GWAS for circulating FGF23 Identifies Novel Network Interactions Between HRG-HMGB1 and Cardiac Disease in CKD

finding: The SNP rs9269041, located near the HLA-DRA gene, showed a significant correlation with PAPS, indicated by a p-value of 2.07×10−8 and an OR of 0.63. This SNP was associated with increased expression of multiple HLA class II genes, highlighting its regulatory role in immune function and the pathogenesis of PAPS.
title: A genome-wide association study suggests new susceptibility loci for primary antiphospholipid syndrome

finding: The SNP rs204999 was associated with high transcript levels of LY6G5B in whole blood, correlating with a high risk for coronary artery disease (CAD), with an odds ratio (OR) of 7.10 [95% CI: 4.34 – 11.64]. This finding was specific to East Asian populations.
title: Integrative multi-ethnic Mendelian randomisation identifies tissue-specific causal genes for Coronary Artery Disease and interactions with post-acute Covid

finding: The SNP rs707920 was linked to protective effects against CAD, associated with LY6G5B transcript levels in lung tissues, yielding an odds ratio (OR) of 0.81 [95% CI: 0.75 – 0.89]. This result indicated a small protective effect in East Asian populations.
title: Integrative multi-ethnic Mendelian randomisation identifies tissue-specific causal genes for Coronary Artery Disease and interactions with post-acute Covid

finding: The rs41266701 SNP was significantly associated with high transcript levels of RPS18 in whole blood, with a corresponding high risk for CAD, indicated by an odds ratio (OR) of 4.27 [95% CI: 2.36 – 7.71]. This was a notable finding for East Asians.
title: Integrative multi-ethnic Mendelian randomisation identifies tissue-specific causal genes for Coronary Artery Disease and interactions with post-acute Covid

finding: At the HLA locus, rs9270887 was associated with increased transcription of the gene HLA-DRB1 due to binding of the risk allele which showed significant regulatory activity specifically in macrophages.
title: Deciphering the functional impact of Alzheimer’s Disease-associated variants in resting and proinflammatory immune cells

finding: The SNP rs35248896 was identified as the strongest associated locus for current medication-use within the human leucocyte antigens (HLA) complex, with a remarkably low p-value of 1.52×10^-46. This genetic variant was linked to the MHC class II gene, specifically HLA-DQA1, highlighting the significant role of the MHC region on chromosome 6 in modulating medication-use and its related complexities, given its involvement in immune response and association with various diseases.
title: The genetic architecture of medication-use

finding: The common variants rs3857615 was identified as an eQTL in cerebellum tissues, emphasizing its link to brain volume traits, particularly in CSF volume.
title: Mapping rare protein-coding variants on multi-organ imaging traits

finding: The common variant rs9475654 was similarly noted as an eQTL in cerebellum hemisphere, supporting its involvement in brain morphology and related traits.
title: Mapping rare protein-coding variants on multi-organ imaging traits

finding: The SNP rs6903956 was associated with the gene Gata2, which was identified as a potential key transcription factor that regulates key crosstalk genes in the context of intracranial aneurysms (IAs) and periodontitis (PD). The study highlighted that Gata2 preferentially interacts with the G allele of the cad susceptibility gene ADTRP, suggesting that this interaction may play a significant role in the co-pathogenesis of IAs and PD by influencing immune reflection mechanisms.
title: The potential crosstalk genes andmolecular mechanismsbetweenintracranial aneurysm and periodontitis

finding: The rs9486715 SNP was identified in the FHL5-UFL1 locus on chromosome 6q16.1 with a significant association to headaches, demonstrating a P value of 6.57 x 10^-39. This SNP was part of the broader analysis confirming associations previously established in studies by Gormley and Meng.
title: A meta-analysis of the genome-wide association studies on two genetically correlated phenotypes (self-reported headache and self-reported migraine) identifies four new risk loci for headaches (N=397,385)

finding: The SNP rs9396861 was identified as a lead SNP at the RNF144B locus for chondrocalcinosis in the AFR cohort with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.49, suggesting increased risk for the disease.
title: Genome-wide association study in chondrocalcinosis reveals ENPP1 as a candidate therapeutic target in calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease

finding: SNP rs1886248 was the lead SNP at the RNF144B locus for chondrocalcinosis in the EUR cohort with an OR of 1.44, indicating it was associated with increased disease risk.
title: Genome-wide association study in chondrocalcinosis reveals ENPP1 as a candidate therapeutic target in calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease

finding: The G (risk) allele of SNP rs6939185 associated with increased expression of ENPP1 in brain tissue, supporting its role as a candidate causal variant for chondrocalcinosis.
title: Genome-wide association study in chondrocalcinosis reveals ENPP1 as a candidate therapeutic target in calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease

finding: SNP rs11963689 was identified as a significant lead SNP at the ENPP1 locus in the AFR cohort of crystal arthropathy, reinforcing its relevance to chondrocalcinosis.
title: Genome-wide association study in chondrocalcinosis reveals ENPP1 as a candidate therapeutic target in calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease

finding: The SNP rs3916765 was associated with cytogenetically normal AML, demonstrating a strong association with an OR of 1.72 and a P-value of 1.51 × 10^-10. This variant mapped to the HLA locus on 6p21.32 and was linked to immune recognition mechanisms related to AML risk.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies susceptibility loci for acute myeloid leukemia

finding: This nonsense variant found in a proband diagnosed with congenital myopathy was reported as pathogenic in multiple ClinVar submissions, underscoring its relevance in muscular dystrophy.
title: Non-coding variants are a rare cause of recessive developmental disorders in trans with coding variants

finding: An intronic 1bp insertion near the splice acceptor of exon 53 in a proband with congenital myopathy was predicted to disrupt splicing based on high predictive scores, highlighting its potential role in muscular dystrophy.
title: Non-coding variants are a rare cause of recessive developmental disorders in trans with coding variants

finding: The SNP at chr6:33061456:C:CT showed a strong association with HBsAg, with a beta of 0.48, standard error of 0.04, and a p-value of 2.6×10−28. The allelic frequency for C was found to be 28.1%. This variant is part of a haplotype containing the protein-coding genes HLA-DPA1 and HLA-DPB1, and this finding was consistent across studies in both CBC and PROVIDE cohorts.
title: Targeting hepatitis B vaccine escape using immunogenetics in Bangladeshi infants

finding: An association was found for the SNP at chr6:32466021:C:T with DT, where the beta was 0.35, standard error was 0.04, and the p-value was 3.0×10−21. The frequency for allele T was reported as 46.7%. This variant resides in a complex HLA haplotype comprising several HLA genes, including HLA-DRB1, HLA-DRB3, HLA-DRB4, HLA-DRB5, HLA-DQA1, and HLA-DQB1.
title: Targeting hepatitis B vaccine escape using immunogenetics in Bangladeshi infants

finding: The SNP chr6:32602046:AAT:A demonstrated a significant association with the pertussis virulence factor PT, presenting a beta of 0.24, a standard error of 0.04, and a p-value of 3.8×10−9. The frequency for AAT was 32.7%. This SNP is located within the HLA-DR and HLA-DQ haplotypes which were previously identified.
title: Targeting hepatitis B vaccine escape using immunogenetics in Bangladeshi infants

finding: For the SNP chr6:32635710:T:C, a significant association was detected for the pertussis virulence factor PRN, with a beta of -0.29, a standard error of 0.04, and a p-value of 4.0×10−14. The frequency for T was found to be 48.3%. This variant is also situated within the same HLA-DR and HLA-DQ haplotypes as other variants mentioned.
title: Targeting hepatitis B vaccine escape using immunogenetics in Bangladeshi infants

finding: The non-synonymous SNP rs763780 in the IL17f gene was associated with susceptibility to tuberculosis and advanced disease severity in a study conducted in Argentina, indicating its relevance to disease phenotypes.
title: Using population-specific add-on polymorphisms to improve genotype imputation in underrepresented populations

finding: The variant rs10499197 was found to be located near an enhancer upstream of TNFAIP3 and was shown to impair TNFAIP3 expression, enhancing the risk for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Functional characterization demonstrated that edits around this SNP could disrupt enhancer activity, thus supporting its role as a causal variant in SLE pathogenesis.
title: A novel regulatory element upstream of TNFAIP3 promoter may be influenced by SLE risk variants

finding: Similar to rs10499197, the variant rs58905141 was reported as overlapping the putative enhancer region approximately 55 kb upstream of TNFAIP3. This finding suggested that it might affect enhancer function and consequently impact TNFAIP3 expression, thereby contributing to SLE risk.
title: A novel regulatory element upstream of TNFAIP3 promoter may be influenced by SLE risk variants

finding: The SNP rs9360616 was associated with long sleep duration, noting its colocalization with another SNP in KCNQ5 that impacted sleep duration significantly.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide analysis identifies common genetic variants for self-reported sleep duration and shared genetic effects

finding: SNP rs6909225, associated with KCNQ5, was identified in the context of long sleep duration and was linked to visual acuity traits, suggesting its broader phenotype implications.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide analysis identifies common genetic variants for self-reported sleep duration and shared genetic effects

finding: The rs2894251 SNP was identified as a significant GWAS signal within the European (EUR) population with a p-value of 2.144 e-15 and a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.12. However, it was not significant in the East Asian (EAS) population where the p-value was 0.05156 and the MAF was 0.02. This finding indicated a difference in association with schizophrenia (SCZ) risk genes between the EUR and EAS populations, highlighting the influence of allele frequency and linkage disequilibrium (LD) patterns.
title: Brain transcriptional regulatory architecture and schizophrenia etiology converge between East Asian and European ancestral populations

finding: The rs2894254 SNP was noted as an associated eSNP for the risk gene C4A, which is linked to SCZ. It was described as extremely uncommon in the East Asian (EAS) population with a MAF of less than 0.001, while it had a MAF of 6% in the European (EUR) population. This disparity in allele frequency contributed to the challenges in detecting common SCZ risk genes in EAS compared to EUR, suggesting that population-specific genetic architecture may limit the identification of risk factors.
title: Brain transcriptional regulatory architecture and schizophrenia etiology converge between East Asian and European ancestral populations

finding: Located on chromosome 6 at 6q21 and associated with z=6.64, this SNP significantly influenced the gene FOXO3, known for its role in oligodendrocyte progenitor cell differentiation and brain injury repair.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: The synonymous SNP rs7738892 in KIF6 was associated with facial traits, particularly contributing to insights on facial development related to spine morphology and cilia.
title: Novel genetic loci affecting facial shape variation in humans

finding: This SNP was identified as newly FDR significant after leveraging functional genomic data, included in the 12 newly significant SNPs with high GenoCanyon scores.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: This SNP was part of the 12 newly significant SNPs identified after applying Flexible cFDR which had high GenoCanyon scores.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: Identified as newly FDR significant alongside others with high GenoCanyon scores and subsequently validated.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: This SNP was included in the newly significant SNPs identified using Flexible cFDR and had high GenoCanyon scores.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: Identified as one of the 12 SNPs that became FDR significant after employing the Flexible cFDR approach.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: Discovered as a newly significant SNP with high functionality, marking it among the 12 identified with high GenoCanyon scores.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: Part of the 12 SNPs that surfaced as newly FDR significant through the use of high GenoCanyon scores.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: It was among the newly significant SNPs recognized post-Flexible cFDR application, having a high GenoCanyon score.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: This SNP, significant due to high H3K27ac counts in asthma relevant cell types, was newly identified through Flexible cFDR.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: Newly identified as significant with a very high H3K27ac fold change indicating its relevance in asthma susceptibility.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: This SNP was identified as newly FDR significant leveraging functional data and was noted for its regulatory region variant properties.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: The SNP rs145578678, located in an intron of the DEK gene, was found to have a suggestive association with the rate of cognitive decline in Alzheimer’s disease, indicated by a significant p-value of 3E-6. This suggested that genetic variation in DEK could influence the odds of late-onset Alzheimer's disease, highlighting the potential importance of DEK in AD pathology, particularly in relation to tau pathology in early disease stages.
title: The proto-oncogene DEK regulates neuronal excitability and tau accumulation in Alzheimer’s disease vulnerable neurons

finding: SNP rs9349379 was found within a TGIF boundary and located in the intronic region of the gene PHACTR1. This SNP was associated with coronary artery atherosclerotic disease and was predicted to be in a regulatory enhancer region, indicating its potential role in affecting gene regulation through alterations in 3D genome structure.
title: Examining dynamics of three-dimensional genome organization with multi-task matrix factorization

finding: The SNP rs9350250 was strongly associated with the accessibility of a narrow peak in RNM 24 and influenced RNM scores for multiple RNMs including 2, 3, 8, 24, and 37. It was found to disrupt 100% of the peak's intramodular co-accessibility, thereby affecting the integrity of RNM. This SNP was associated with decreased accessibility of several primed-associated RNMs and increased accessibility of formative-associated RNMs, indicating its role in influencing pluripotency states.
title: Unsupervised Machine Learning Identifies Chromatin Accessibility Regulatory Networks that Define Cell State Transitions in Pluripotency

finding: The IL-17A rs2275913 single nucleotide polymorphism was found to be associated with protection against tuberculosis (TB) while simultaneously correlating with higher disease severity in an Argentinian cohort. This finding was particularly important as it linked genetic variation to the immune response in TB, where increased IL-17A expression was observed in patients with active TB.
title: Exaggerated in vivo IL-17 responses discriminate recall responses in active TB

finding: The SNP rs2388334 represented a peak association located 700 kb upstream of POU3F2 with a p-value of 1.0e-6, suggesting its relevance to ASD through regulatory interactions involving POU3F2, a key transcription factor implicated in neurodevelopment.
title: Transcriptome-wide transmission disequilibrium analysis identifies novel risk genes for autism spectrum disorder

finding: The SNP rs62422661 had a p-value of 2.0e-5 within the GWAS framework and was found to be significantly interacting with the promoter region of POU3F2 in the postmitotic-zone cortical plate, further supporting its relevance to the regulatory network associated with ASD.
title: Transcriptome-wide transmission disequilibrium analysis identifies novel risk genes for autism spectrum disorder

finding: The SNP rs2763979 in the HSPA1B gene was identified as a significant variant associated with asthma. Specifically, this study demonstrated that the presence of this variant influenced the risk assessment for asthma, highlighting its role in disease pathology and potential utility in diagnostic and prognostic contexts for asthma management.
title: Deciphering the Immune Subtypes and Signature Genes: A Novel Approach Towards Diagnosing and Prognosticating Severe Asthma through Interpretable Machine Learning

finding: The SNP rs6912739 was associated with a conserved target site for miR-151-5p, which is highly expressed in testes. It was noted that this target site associated with the gene CYB5R4, linked to oxidative stress protection in sperm production, was not detected in the reference genome. The study highlighted that the loss of the ancestral target site associated with rs6912739 occurred specifically in European populations, whereas the target allele was predominantly retained in other human populations. This finding underscored the influence of population dynamics on the detection of microRNA target sites that are absent in reference genomes.
title: PopTargs: A database for studying population evolutionary genetics of human microRNA target sites

finding: The rs10080260 SNP was connected to the inhibition of TGF-betaR1, indicating that it could suppress tumor growth and ascites development in ovarian cancer. This was demonstrated in both clinical and cellular models relevant to the disease, reinforcing its significance in modulating ECM dynamics in HGSOC.
title: Modelling TGFβR and Hh pathway regulation of prognostic matrisome molecules in ovarian cancer

finding: The polymorphism rs6918698 in the promoter region of the CTGF gene was associated with an increased risk of scleroderma, particularly interstitial lung fibrosis in systemic sclerosis patients. This finding indicated that homozygosity for the G allele resulted in a heightened risk, emphasizing the role of CTGF upregulation in fibrotic diseases.
title: Connective-Tissue Growth Factor (CTGF/CCN2) Contributes to TGF-β1-Induced Lung Fibrosis

finding: The SNP rs28411362 was associated with the MTF1 gene and formed a three-dimensional contact with its promoter in SFs exposed to synergistic cytokines. Its involvement in chromatin remodeling was highlighted as critical for cytokine and chemokine production, indicating its relevance in RA pathogenesis.
title: Parsing multiomics landscape of activated synovial fibroblasts highlights drug targets linked to genetic risk of rheumatoid arthritis

finding: The SNP rs6902725 exhibited association with two traits in opposite directions and contributed to the understanding of blood pressure traits.
title: Multivariate Genomewide Association Analysis with IHT

finding: This SNP regulated different butyrophilin alleles, specifically BTN2A2 in adult and BTN3A1 in fetal cortex, indicating its diverse roles in immune modulation relevant to ASD.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: Similar to rs13218591, rs2237234 functioned as an eQTL regulating different butyrophilin genes in fetal and adult cortex, further stressing its involvement in ASD-linked immune pathways.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: This SNP was associated with increased transcript levels of TAP2 in both fetal and adult tissues, indicating its contribution to ASD-related pathways.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: This SNP was connected to reduced transcript levels of HLA-DRB1 in fetal cortex, demonstrating its relevance within the immunological pathways affected by ASD.
title: Autism spectrum disorder: understanding the impact of SNPs on biological pathways in the fetal and adult cortex

finding: The study identified rs77910749 as a human-specific candidate causal variant located within the LC1 enhancer upstream of POU3F2. This variant, a single-base deletion in a PAX6 binding site, was shown to increase enhancer activity in both developing mouse cerebral cortex and human iPSC-derived cerebral organoids. Mice with the rs77910749 knock-in exhibited significant behavioral defects in sensory gating, a phenotype relevant to bipolar disorder.
title: A candidate causal variant underlying both higher intelligence and increased risk of bipolar disorder

finding: RS9320913 was pinpointed as the lead SNP in multiple GWAS studies focused on educational attainment, which is a proxy for cognitive performance. It was associated with a genome-wide significant signal in the intergenic region implicated in bipolar disorder and intelligence.
title: A candidate causal variant underlying both higher intelligence and increased risk of bipolar disorder

finding: This proxy variant for rs9320913 was associated with increased general cognitive ability in meta-analyses, supporting the genetic linkage between intelligence and the MIR2113/POU3F2 region.
title: A candidate causal variant underlying both higher intelligence and increased risk of bipolar disorder

finding: Similar to rs1906252, rs10457441 was confirmed as a proxy variant related to greater general cognitive ability in GWAS meta-analyses, further solidifying the connection between this intergenic region and cognitive performance.
title: A candidate causal variant underlying both higher intelligence and increased risk of bipolar disorder

finding: Identified as a lead SNP associated with approximately 10-20% increased risk for bipolar disorder in a GWAS study of Caucasian subjects, rs12202969 demonstrated a significant genetic link to BD within the intergenic region.
title: A candidate causal variant underlying both higher intelligence and increased risk of bipolar disorder

finding: This proxy variant was in high linkage disequilibrium with rs12202969, reaffirming the association with bipolar disorder risk in subsequent GWAS studies.
title: A candidate causal variant underlying both higher intelligence and increased risk of bipolar disorder

finding: The SNP rs74405933, associated with rheumatoid arthritis, was identified as disrupting a predicted NFκB/RELA binding site, which was linked to the expression of CD83, a gene critical for B cell activation and maturation.
title: Integrated single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics reveals strong germinal center-associated etiology of autoimmune risk loci

finding: The analysis highlighted rs3020314 as an anchor SNP in the ESR1 gene associated with breast cancer, having significant supportive analysis with multiple SNPs in its LD block.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: The SNP rs2982689 was part of a group of six SNPs prioritized for strong association with breast cancer based on their assigned weights during analysis.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: Identified as one of the strong contributors in the linear combinations leading to breast cancer association, particularly when combined with rs2982689.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: Noted as one of the six SNPs receiving high weights leading to breast cancer association in the ESR1 gene.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: This SNP was incorporated into the analysis that identified associations with breast cancer risk among the six prioritized SNPs in the ESR1 gene.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: Discovered as a notable SNP in a risk association analysis for breast cancer risk, attributed with high weight in analyses within ESR1.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: Notable for its contribution in analyses indicating associations with breast cancer, part of a larger set that included six significant SNPs.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: This SNP was identified as a new possible association with breast cancer, adding to the list of critical SNPs analyzed within the ESR1 gene context.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: This SNP was identified within gene regulatory regions and linked to potential effects on the BACH2 gene functioning in Treg cells, critical for T1D mechanisms.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: SNP rs905671 showed evidence of impacting regulatory mechanisms associated with BACH2 expression, potentially influencing Treg activity in autoimmune contexts.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: The SNP rs943689 was found to be associated with BACH2 regulatory activity, implicating it in Treg function and T1D pathogenesis.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: This SNP was located in a T cell-specific enhancer region and was found to disrupt Forkhead proteins binding, potentially affecting BACH2 expression and T1D progression.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: The SNP rs200847762 within the FKBPL gene had an original finding with the smallest discovery P-value reported by Jin et al. (P = 1.84×10-6). The odds ratio (OR) was found to be 0.21 during the discovery stage and replicated in the first replication study (OR = 0.19, 95% Confidence Interval: (0.08 – 0.46)). In the second replication study, the estimated OR was 0.66, with a confidence interval of (0.34 – 1.28) that included one. The Mix Bayes approach produced a posterior estimate of OR equal to 0.27, suggesting a genuine causal signal in this region.
title: Quantifying posterior effect size distribution of susceptibility loci by common summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs2298090 within the HIST1H1E gene had the second smallest P-value in Jin et al.'s discovery study (P = 6.16×10-5). Although it displayed a trend towards significance with an OR of 0.65 in the second replication stage, the confidence interval of (0.44 – 1.02) indicated no significant effect. The Mix Bayes posterior mean estimate was found to be OR = 0.48, with the 95% interval (0.24-1.01), suggesting a potential weak association.
title: Quantifying posterior effect size distribution of susceptibility loci by common summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs9469031 within the BAT2 gene had a discovery P-value of approximately 10-4 and was replicated in the second stage of Jin et al.'s study. The Mix Bayes estimate provided a lower effect size magnitude with an OR = 0.68, reflecting more closely the replication values rather than the original estimate.
title: Quantifying posterior effect size distribution of susceptibility loci by common summary statistics

finding: While rs9469301 was mentioned, it was referred to as 'rs9469031' in the text. The Mix Bayes estimate indicated an OR = 0.68 and a posterior interval of (0.43 – 1.07), showing a significant uncertainty with a tendency closer to the replication study values.
title: Quantifying posterior effect size distribution of susceptibility loci by common summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs3135388, which tags the HLA-DRB1*15:01 allele, was associated with Multiple Sclerosis (MS). It was included in the calculation of the MS Genetic Burden Score (MSGB), which is derived from a number of MS risk alleles weighted by their effect sizes as identified in large GWAS meta-analyses. This finding suggested that rs3135388 contributes significantly to the genetic risk of developing MS.
title: Multiscale networks in multiple sclerosis

finding: The SNP rs833061 in VEGF-A was found to be predictive of PFS and OS in patients receiving bevacizumab treatment, emphasizing its significance in colorectal cancer.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: The SNP rs483481, located in the OPRM1 gene, was associated with the risk for heroin use disorder. This finding provided insights into how genetic variations could influence susceptibility to addictive behaviors related to opioids, thereby linking the genetic polymorphism to the broader context of morphine's effects on neural gene expression and chromatin architecture.
title: Morphine Re-arranges Chromatin Spatial Architecture of Primate Cortical Neurons

finding: SNP rs6931421 was included in the GWAS of SHR and was replicated in the EUR-specific meta-analysis of 473,511 individuals, reaching genome-wide significance in both studies.
title: Genetics of skeletal proportions in two different populations

finding: The intronic SNP rs11154337 was found to control the regulation of NCOA7 expression and was associated with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) disease severity and mortality. Specifically, the G allele of rs11154337 conferred improved six-minute walk distance and significantly enhanced survival rates among PAH patients, with a hazard ratio of 0.44 in a discovery cohort and 0.49 in a validation cohort, suggesting its protective role in EC immunoactivation and metabolic pathways linked to PAH.
title: Genetic regulation and targeted reversal of lysosomal dysfunction and inflammatory sterol metabolism in pulmonary arterial hypertension

finding: The SNP rs433061 was found to regulate the CO4A protein levels and was identified as a top hit from the univariate analyses. It colocalized with numerous epigenomic marks and functioned as a known eQTL for the C4A gene, suggesting a pleiotropic role in metabolic pathways.
title: A large-scale multivariate pQTL study sheds light on the genetic architecture of obesity

finding: rs641153 was identified as a sentinel pQTL for the CFAB protein and was found to affect transcription factor binding sites. It was recognized as an eQTL for NELFE and SKIV2L but not for CFB, signaling its regulatory role in obesity-related pathways.
title: A large-scale multivariate pQTL study sheds light on the genetic architecture of obesity

finding: The SNP rs13194734 demonstrated relevance to gene expression profiling for precision oncology in Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC). This highlighted the significance of specific genetic markers in the context of targeted cancer therapies.
title: Gene Expression Profiling Unveils the Temporal Dynamics of CIGB-300-Regulated Transcriptome in AML Cells

finding: The SNP rs13205205 was positively associated with breast cancer outcomes, particularly regarding its relevance to the gene FOXA1. FOXA1 was highlighted in the study as having dual roles in cancer and was a part of the identified gene expression signature in non-malignant mammary tissue. This relationship suggested that the presence of this SNP could be linked to tumor biology and patient survival outcomes.
