title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: The minor allele of this SNP was linked to decreased total SA, showing a P-value of 2.5 x 10^-10 with a replicated P-value of 2.5 x 10^-13. It was also previously associated with lower general cognitive function.
title: The genetic architecture of the human cerebral cortex

finding: In a case-control study on prostate cancer, it was found that the PSA level increased consistently as the minor allele count for rs851023 went from 0 to 2. This suggests a relationship between the rs851023 SNP and prostate cancer susceptibility, particularly indicated by increasing PSA levels across different genotypes.
title: Testing monotonic trends among multiple group means against a composite null

finding: The G allele of rs79967607 was associated with a 41% decrease in geometric mean percent pancreatic fat (Beta = -0.90, P = 4.91x10^-8) and explained 3.6% of the variance in pancreatic fat. It was most common in European Americans (6%) and had a significant association with pancreatic fat in this sub-group (Beta = -1.08, P = 1.31x10^-6), although there were no associations noted with type 2 diabetes.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Pancreatic Fat: The Multiethnic Cohort Adiposity Phenotype Study

finding: The effects of the new sentinel variant rs72959041 at the RSPO3 locus were significantly altered when adjusted for WHR and BMI, with an unadjusted p-value of 2.1×10-10 and an adjusted p-value of 3.4×10-40. RSPO3 is involved in the Wnt pathway and has connections to adiposity and blood trait variation, demonstrating its importance in hematological outcomes.
title: Obesity and adiposity have opposing genetic impacts on human blood traits

finding: The SNP rs1064173-A was found to be the most significantly associated SNP with overall autoimmune diseases, with a p-value of 2.74×10^-36 and an odds ratio of 1.80 (95% CI: 1.64-1.96). This finding was derived from a genome-wide association study involving 1,383 patients with autoimmune diseases and 62,656 controls, and it highlighted its relevance in the context of genetic predisposition to autoimmune disorders.
title: Genetic factors underlying the bidirectional relationship between autoimmune and mental disorders – findings from a Danish population-based study

finding: The variant rs1998266 was implicated as an eQTL for ETV7, where the alternative allele C upregulated gene expression in stimulated cells. It was associated with autoimmune conditions and indicated its significance in modulating immune responses.
title: Mapping interindividual dynamics of innate immune response at single-cell resolution

finding: This SNP was the lead for a novel signal near C6orf106 and was validated as increasing gene expression in the associated region.
title: Ancestral diversity improves discovery and fine-mapping of genetic loci for anthropometric traits - the Hispanic/Latino Anthropometry Consortium

finding: The variant DAXX A486G, identified specifically in sample GOE615, demonstrated significant effects on the expression of three markers: GADD45B, LOXL4, and ACKR3, with a false discovery rate (FDR) of less than 0.05. GADD45B pathways are associated with p53 signaling and ATM/ATR regulation of the DNA damage response.
title: A novel single-cell RNA-sequencing platform and its applicability connecting genotype to phenotype in ageing-disease

finding: The rs29269 SNP was identified as one among the lead SNPs associated with platelet counts, an immune-mediated phenotype. It was found to be located within a well-positioned Fiber-seq nucleosome footprint, suggesting its potential regulatory role related to chromatin accessibility.
title: A haplotype-resolved view of human gene regulation

finding: The rs4713235 SNP also emerged as a lead SNP in the study, noted for directly disrupting single-molecule Fiber-seq transcription factor occupancy at a CTCF binding element. This disruption indicates a significant effect on the regulation of elements within the HLA locus.
title: A haplotype-resolved view of human gene regulation

finding: The variant rs12203592 at chromosome 6p25.3 had its major T allele associated with a younger age at first sexual intercourse and an increased risk of mortality. Moreover, the T allele frequency increased over 25 years and was linked to decreased parental lifespan and increased risk of multiple cancers, including melanoma and lung cancer.
title: Evidence for the role of selection for reproductively advantageous alleles in human aging

finding: The SNP rs9267835 was defined as pathogenic by all four algorithms used in the analysis, highlighting its potential influence on neuroticism through pathogenic effects.
title: Gene-based association analysis identified 190 genes with polymorphisms affecting neuroticism

finding: Similarly, the SNP rs6986 was associated with neuroticism in prior studies and was recognized as a potentially pathogenic variant.
title: Gene-based association analysis identified 190 genes with polymorphisms affecting neuroticism

finding: The SNP rs12203592, located in the IRF4 gene, was found to be independently associated with eye colour, suggesting a significant role in the pigmentation process.
title: Investigating the genetic architecture of eye colour in a Canadian cohort

finding: The lead SNP on chromosome 6 overlapping the ILRUN gene, rs116072038, was significantly associated with eye colour for the first time.
title: Investigating the genetic architecture of eye colour in a Canadian cohort

finding: The analysis indicated that the targeting of the rs72928038 risk locus using a dCas9-p300 variant influenced BACH2 gene expression in K562 cells. This finding was derived from RT-qPCR experiments, which reported an effect on the expression levels of the BACH2 gene following the targeting. This SNP was noted for its involvement in the regulatory mechanisms of gene expression linked to epigenetic modifications.
title: Tailoring a CRISPR/Cas-based Epigenome Editor for Programmable Chromatin Acylation and Decreased Cytotoxicity

finding: The rs41272114 splice site mutation was associated with significantly lower mean Lp(a) concentrations (-12.26 mg/dL, p=3.18e-29). It was highlighted as a proxy for R21X, and virtually all R21X carriers were found to carry rs41272114, indicating a strong linkage disequilibrium. This variant has been repeatedly shown to be protective against coronary artery disease.
title: Investigation of an LPA KIV-2 nonsense mutation in 11,000 individuals: the importance of linkage disequilibrium structure in LPA genetics

finding: The SNP rs807701 was associated with reading ability, indicating that variations in the DCDC2 gene could significantly influence academic performance, particularly in language-related tasks. Previous studies highlighted that mutations in the DCDC2 gene led to reading difficulties, establishing a link between genetic factors and educational outcomes.
title: Correlation analysis among single nucleotide polymorphisms in thirteen language genes and culture/education parameters from twenty-six countries

finding: The T allele at rs12203592 in the <italic>Interferon Regulatory Factor 4</italic> (<italic>IRF4</italic>) gene was associated with an increased risk for <italic>de novo</italic> acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.38 (95% CI, 1.26-1.51, P<sub>meta</sub>=2.8×10<sup>−12</sup>). Additionally, increased <italic>IRF4</italic> gene expression was correlated with a significantly elevated risk of developing these conditions (OR=3.90, P<sub>meta</sub>=1.0×10<sup>−7</sup>). This variant's identification shed light on common variants related to the susceptibility of these hematological disorders.
title: Genome-wide association analyses identify variants in IRF4 associated with Acute Myeloid Leukemia and Myelodysplastic Syndrome susceptibility

finding: The A allele at rs62389423, which is in modest linkage disequilibrium (r<sub>2</sub>=0.7) with rs12203592, showed a putative association with an increased risk of <italic>de novo</italic> AML and MDS (OR=1.36; 95% CI, 1.21-1.52, P<sub>meta</sub>=1.2×10<sup>−7</sup>). This association further supports the role of the <italic>IRF4</italic> regulatory region in the susceptibility to these diseases.
title: Genome-wide association analyses identify variants in IRF4 associated with Acute Myeloid Leukemia and Myelodysplastic Syndrome susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs142986308, which resulted in the nonsynonymous amino acid substitution p.Arg587Trp in the CCHCR1 gene, was associated with susceptibility to alopecia areata (AA). The study demonstrated that mice carrying this variant exhibited a patchy hair loss phenotype. Additionally, keratin abnormalities were identified in the hair shaft, along with differential expression of hair-related keratin genes in both alopecic mice and hair follicles from AA patients, thereby confirming the relevance of this SNP in the context of AA pathogenesis.
title: The alopecia areata phenotype is induced by the water avoidance stress test in cchcr1-deficient mice

finding: This rare variant was positively associated with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and found to have greater effect sizes than variants in gnomAD. It was hypothesized that it is a gain-of-function mutation linked to ASD, wherein variants overlapping PASs in cases were enriched for gain-of-function compared to controls.
title: Deciphering the Impact of Genetic Variation on Human Polyadenylation

finding: The variant rs3800461 on the gene C6orf106 was found to be implicated in autophagy, indicating a relevant connection between this SNP and the cellular mechanism of autophagy, which is significant in the context of Autism Spectrum Disorder.
title: Personalized Perturbation Profiles Reveal Concordance between Autism Blood Transcriptome Datasets

finding: The SNP rs10455872 was associated with increased risk for all-cause and cardiovascular mortality. Carriers of at least one Lp(a) raising allele (AG or GG genotype) had a hazard ratio of 1.14 (95% CI, 1.07-1.22) for all-cause mortality with an event rate of 31.9%, and a hazard ratio of 1.23 (95% CI, 1.11-1.36) for cardiovascular mortality with an event rate of 13.9%. These findings indicated that presence of this SNP significantly affected mortality outcomes.
title: Long-Term Exposure to Elevated Lipoprotein(a) Levels, Parental Lifespan and Risk of Mortality

finding: The study identified that the SNP rs610913 was associated with the cGAS-STING pathway, revealing that this variant can maintain a baseline antiviral state. The research highlighted that the natural occurrence of this variant impacted the cellular response to SARS-CoV-2, particularly in the context of antiviral pathways and cellular tropism influenced by ACE2 expression.
title: A basally active cGAS-STING pathway limits SARS-CoV-2 replication in a subset of ACE2 positive airway cell models

finding: The rs66475830 SNP, associated with AMD, was accessible in amacrine and horizontal cells. It showed a significant correlation with TSPYL4 expression via eQTL analysis, suggesting that TSPYL4 is the effector gene influenced by this SNP.
title: Single-cell multiome of the human retina and deep learning nominate causal variants in complex eye diseases

finding: The HFE rs1800562 variant was replicated as negatively associated with age in the analyses, adding to the understanding of genetic influences on aging.
title: Exome-wide association studies in general and long-lived populations identify genetic variants related to human age

finding: The SNP rs365052, located on chromosome 6, served as a local eQTL for ZFP57 and also acted as a meQTL for multiple clustered CpG-sites on chromosome 20, located proximal to ZFP57-binding sites within the promoter of GNAS-AS1. This SNP was associated with body size and demonstrated significant effects on methylation, particularly upstream of the GNAS-AS1 transcriptional start site.
title: Genetic control of KRAB-ZFP genes explains distal CpG-site methylation which associates with human disease phenotypes

finding: SNP rs9263745 corresponded to gene CCHCR1, associated with numerous genetic diseases.
title: Locating suspicious lethal genes by abnormal distributions of SNP patterns

finding: The study indicated that the SNP rs610913 was associated with a baseline cellular antiviral state maintained by the cGAS pathway. Specifically, it was found that this naturally occurring variant contributed to the antiviral immune response, impacting the ability of the immune system to respond to HIV-1 infection. This was significant as it highlighted the role of genetic variation in shaping immune response to viral infections, including HIV-1.
title: Type I interferons sensitise HIV-1-reactivating T-cells for NK cell-mediated elimination despite HDACi-imposed dysregulation of innate immunity

finding: The SNP rs1906953, located at 6p21.3 within the glutamate receptor metabotropic 4 (GRM4) gene, was identified as a susceptibility locus for osteosarcoma achieving genome-wide significance. Although not biochemically confirmed, it was believed that this intronic variant enhances the transcription of the GRM4 gene, which showed overexpression in the majority of osteosarcomas. Pharmacological treatments targeting glutamate receptors, such as the Riluzole antagonist, were reported to inhibit cancer cell proliferation and migration. This suggested a potential regulatory role of neurotransmitter receptors, particularly in the context of osteosarcomas, hinting at a complex interplay that could influence tumor progression and metastasis.
title: Vitamin D inhibits osteosarcoma by reprogramming nonsense-mediated RNA decay and SNAI2-mediated epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition

finding: The rs2175898 polymorphism in the ESR1 gene was shown to have a significant sex-specific effect on obesity, indicating a potential genetic influence on body weight regulation.
title: Identification of novel key genes and signaling pathways in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: evidence from bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The rs45527431 SNP showed a significant association with schizophrenia, suggesting that the risk alleles for both schizophrenia and left-handedness had the same direction of effect.
title: RSGenome-wide association study identifies 49 common genetic variants associated with handedness

finding: The rs9405472 SNP, located in the FOXF2 locus, was found to be a significant intronic variant associated with anterior segment dysgenesis in a genome-wide association study of retinal fundus images. Its minor allele frequency was noted to be 0.4279, with a p-value of 2.0·10^-11, highlighting its relevance in eye-related traits.
title: transferGWAS: GWAS of images using deep transfer learning

finding: The SNP rs9356013 at the PARK2 locus was identified as a novel population-specific GWAS signal associated with age-at-onset (AAO) for Parkinson's disease (PD) in the Spanish population. It exhibited a significant association with a corrected p-value of 4.44 E-13, specifically noted in the Spanish cohort, with no parallel findings in other international datasets. This SNP was carried in homozygous and heterozygous states among PD cases, impacting AAO, where homozygous carriers had a mean AAO of 42.67 years compared to 60.07 years for heterozygous carriers. Whole-genome sequencing in homozygous carriers revealed a deleterious frameshift mutation at PARK2, suggesting a complex interplay of SNP rs9356013 and the c.155delA variant as likely dependent signals.
title: The genetic architecture of Parkinson disease in Spain: characterizing population-specific risk, differential haplotype structures, and providing etiologic insight

finding: The single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs6903956 on chromosome 6p24.1 was identified as a genetic risk factor for coronary artery disease (CAD), with a reported adjusted odds ratio of 1.65 in a large Chinese cohort study. The presence of the 'A' allele at rs6903956 was associated with increased risk of coronary atherosclerosis. Additionally, in induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) derived from CAD patients, elimination of this risk allele downregulated pathways related to abnormal vascular physiology and endothelial activation.
title: Trans-interaction of risk loci 6p24.1 and 10q11.21 is associated with endothelial damage in coronary artery disease

finding: The lead variant rs6902879 at 6q16 was suggestively associated with increased expression of the MCHR2 gene, with an effect allele of A, EAF of 0.16, beta of -0.08, standard error of 0.01, and a P value of 5.3×10^-8 in the African ancestry GWAS. This SNP is located upstream of the MCHR2 gene and was linked to increased expression in the cortex, with a significant P value of 6.0×10^-6 based on Genotype-Tissue Expression (GTEx v8). Additionally, significant colocalisation with GRIK2 and ASCC3 was noted.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS of major depression aids locus discovery, fine-mapping, gene prioritisation, and causal inference

finding: The rs3094127 SNP (T>C) in the last intron of the FLOT1 gene was found to be associated with an increased risk of invasive aspergillosis (IA) in hematopoietic stem-cell transplant recipients. Specifically, the cumulative incidence of IA was observed to be 38.5% for the CC genotype, 29.6% for the TC genotype, and 19.6% for the TT genotype. Additionally, in a multivariate model, the CC genotype at rs3094127 was identified as an independent predictor of IA with a hazard ratio of 1.89 (95% CI 1.14-5.67; p=0.03). Macrophages from individuals carrying this SNP produced significantly lower levels of IL-1β and IL-6 when stimulated with A. fumigatus conidia, indicating a functional impact of the SNP on immune response.
title: Flotillin-dependent lipid-raft microdomains are required for functional phagolysosomes against fungal infections

finding: The SNP rs13194864 was associated with the AXL receptor's involvement in cancer metastasis and drug resistance, particularly enhancing the invasive properties of MITF<sup>Low</sup> melanoma cells. This was linked to the ligand-independent activation of AXL by fatty acids like oleic acid, which drove a pro-metastatic phenotype.
title: Phenotype-specific melanoma uptake of fatty acid from human adipocytes activates AXL and CAV1-dependent β-catenin nuclear accumulation

finding: Found to impact body height and smoking behavior, rs114627468 was linked to GWAS peaks providing strong evidence of its involvement in regulatory pathways influencing diverse phenotypes.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: This SNP, part of a haplotype correlating with smoking behavior, showed evidence connecting it to neuropsychiatric conditions through gene expression modulation mechanisms.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: This index SNP served as an ASB SNP for TAF1 and was correlated with various traits linked to intellectual behavior and mental health disorders.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: As a SNP coinciding with numerous traits within the wellbeing spectrum, it linked to risk assessments related to cognitive and physical health outcomes.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: The intergenic SNP rs7747253 located in the HLA region showed selection related to heel bone mineral density, with frequency reductions starting around 8,000 years ago, indicating complex patterns of immune-related selection in response to environmental pressures.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: The SNP rs9267677, associated with educational attainment, demonstrated a gradual increase in frequency beginning around 4,000 years ago, reflecting the dynamic selection processes within the immune-related loci in the HLA region.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: The FKBP5 variant rs1360780 was associated with altered cognitive function in aged individuals. This finding was contextualized within a larger study that indicated potential links between the FKBP5 locus and cognitive traits, particularly emphasizing its relevance in Alzheimer's disease where cognitive decline is prominent.
title: SKA2 regulated hyperactive secretory autophagy drives neuroinflammation-induced neurodegeneration

finding: The SNP rs9357271 was identified as an intronic variant linked solely to restless leg syndrome, showcasing low pleiotropy.
title: Pleiotropic Variability Score: A Genome Interpretation Metric to Quantify Phenomic Associations of Genomic Variants

finding: The variant rs144007943 was identified at the PLA2G7 locus, contributing to significant associations post-conditioning.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing Based Analysis of Inflammation Biomarkers in the Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Consortium

finding: At the PLA2G7 locus, rs74479543 formed part of the distinct signals relevant to analyses of pLOF rare variants.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing Based Analysis of Inflammation Biomarkers in the Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Consortium

finding: The rare variant rs144067869 at the PLA2G7 locus associated with inflammation biomarkers following a rigorous conditioning analysis.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing Based Analysis of Inflammation Biomarkers in the Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Consortium

finding: Lastly, rs150641786 was recognized as a significant exploration at the PLA2G7 locus, contributing to our understanding of complex genetic interactions.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing Based Analysis of Inflammation Biomarkers in the Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Consortium

finding: Identified through analysis, rs140020965 was part of significant associations with rare variants impacting the PLA2G7 locus.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing Based Analysis of Inflammation Biomarkers in the Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Consortium

finding: The involvement of rs200303358 in missense rare variants analysis underscored its contributions to PLA2G7 related findings.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing Based Analysis of Inflammation Biomarkers in the Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Consortium

finding: The variant rs73471140 was found to relate to Lp-PLA2 mass, showcasing its biological relevance post GWAS-guided analyses.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing Based Analysis of Inflammation Biomarkers in the Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Consortium

finding: The SNP rs761357 was suggested as the single causal variant for the AHI1 gene's association with Multiple Sclerosis and Irritable Bowel Syndrome, being identified through MPRA as having the only significant allelic effect despite not being a lead variant in eQTL or GWAS data but closely linked to lead variants in previous studies.
title: Multiple Causal Variants Underlie Genetic Associations in Humans

finding: The SNP rs9271058 was linked to a candidate cis-regulatory element (cCRE) associated with the HLA-DRB1 gene in microglia located in the entorhinal cortex (EC). This cCRE contained transcription factor motifs specific to microglial regulators, indicating its relevance in the context of sporadic early-onset Alzheimer's disease (sEOAD) and late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD).
title: Single-nucleus multiomics reveals the disrupted regulatory programs in three brain regions of sporadic early-onset Alzheimer’s disease

finding: In the study, SNP rs1947413 was characterized as being 354 bp upstream of a validated de novo LINE-1 insertion in hEMB-3. It was genetically linked with the C SNP at this site (termed allele B), confirming its association with the presence of the LINE-1 insertion. Single cell analyses showed that the cells did not possess this insertion, indicating a genetic mosaicism within the embryo.
title: LINE-1 retrotransposition impacts the genome of human pre-implantation embryos and extraembryonic tissues

finding: SNP rs10944957 was located 912 bp downstream of the validated LINE-1 insertion in the hEMB-3 sample, and its presence was also analyzed through PCR and capillary sequencing. The findings confirmed that this SNP's alleles were present in the remaining embryo sample but were not detected in the single cells analyzed, further supporting the concept of genetic mosaicism in relation to the LINE-1 insertion.
title: LINE-1 retrotransposition impacts the genome of human pre-implantation embryos and extraembryonic tissues

finding: This missense variant in KIAA0319 was associated with poor performance in spelling tasks, indicating its relevance in dyslexia-related traits.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: Also a missense variant in KIAA0319, it was linked to poor performance in spelling, further evidencing the genetic basis of dyslexia.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: A variant co-located with other critical SNPs within a 40 bp region in KIAA0319, it was strongly associated with decreased spelling performance.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: As part of the same critical cluster in KIAA0319, this SNP was similarly associated with spelling difficulty indicative of its role in dyslexia.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: In tight linkage disequilibrium with other significant variants, this SNP showed nominal evidence for association with multiple dyslexia phenotypes.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: This variant in KIAA0319 was predicted to disrupt a transcription factor binding site, implicating it in the dyslexia phenotypes related to spelling.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with spelling tasks while showing suggestive evidence for other traits, indicating its regulatory potential in DCDC2.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: Associated significantly with multiple dyslexia-related phenotypes, this SNP provided compelling evidence within the DCDC2 gene.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: The SNP rs12193218 was identified in the context of a study on environmental drivers influencing the movement ecology of both wild and domestic ungulates in semi-arid savannas. The research demonstrated that this SNP was associated with specific behavioral responses to habitat and movement preferences, indicating its relevance in ecological and environmental genetics contexts. This finding contributed valuable insights into how genetic variations may influence species behavior in fluctuating environments.
title: Methods for Implementing Integrated Step-Selection Functions with Incomplete Data

finding: The SNP rs9368219 near CDKAL1 was also associated with age at diagnosis of T2D in South Asians, with a significant p-value of 2.29 × 10^-8 and Beta of -0.053. This finding was consistent across different ethnic groups, although the allelic effect size varied.
title: Common and distinct genetic architecture of age at diagnosis of diabetes in South Indian and European populations

finding: The SNP rs143316471 near CDKAL1 was also found to be a novel variant associated with age of diagnosis of T2D in South Indians (P < 0.0054, Beta -5.3), and showed significantly lower frequency in European cohorts.
title: Common and distinct genetic architecture of age at diagnosis of diabetes in South Indian and European populations

finding: The variant rs76572975 was identified within the PKHD1 gene, a known Mendelian disease gene. It was highlighted as protein-altering and located within a credible set containing four independent signals, presenting it as a compelling candidate for further research into kidney function.
title: Discovery and prioritization of variants and genes for kidney function in >1.2 million individuals

finding: The analysis demonstrated a genome-wide significant association at rs28724235 in the HLA region with a P-value of 2.2×10−11, indicating a subtype-dependent effect on disease susceptibility in MPO+ EGPA.
title: Genetically distinct clinical subsets, and associations with asthma and eosinophil abundance, within Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis

finding: The minor (T) allele of rs9375831, located intronically in ENPP1, was linked with lower TG in both Africans (β -0.55, p=4.1×10⁻⁸) and AA (β -0.076, p=0.037). Variants within ENPP1 have solid connections to insulin resistance-related traits.
title: GWAS in Africans identifies novel lipids loci and demonstrates heterogenous association within Africa

finding: The SNP rs3101018 was also found to have significant regulatory effects in both HepG2 and K562 cells and was associated with schizophrenia. This suggests a possible influence in the genetic underpinnings of schizophrenia.
title: High-throughput functional analysis of IncRNA core promoters elucidatesrules governing tissue-specificity

finding: The SNP rs12202410 was associated with depression only and located near the FBXL4 gene, which plays a role in energy homeostasis.
title: Stratifying depression by neuroticism: revisiting a diagnostic tradition using GWAS data

finding: The SNP rs2677110 was significantly associated with RBA and located within the RUNX2 gene on chromosome 6. RUNX2 encodes a transcription factor that influences osteocalcin expression, and low osteocalcin levels have been linked to age-related cognitive decline, suggesting a connection between this SNP and brain health.
title: Improving brain age estimates with deep learning leads to identification of novel genetic factors associated with brain aging

finding: The SNP rs3129058 was identified as an im-mQTL that modulated LPS-induced methylation at cg16885113, which colocalised with a GWAS risk locus for lung cancer. This variant demonstrated a significant association with methylation changes in response to inflammatory stimuli, highlighting its potential role in cancer predisposition.
title: Characterisation of the genetic determinants of context specific DNA methylation in primary monocytes

finding: The SNP rs417764 affected methylation at 151 CpGs, which clustered in genomic regions enriched for imprinted regions. This SNP was notably associated with LPS responsiveness, where the rs417764:A allele increased the magnitude of methylation change upon LPS stimulation, further linking it to ZFP57 expression and epigenetic regulation.
title: Characterisation of the genetic determinants of context specific DNA methylation in primary monocytes

finding: The SNP rs744103 showed significant associations with pancreatic-related traits and reinforced the connections between pancreatic health and metabolic disorders.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI

finding: The SNP rs237025 (M55V) in the SUMO4 gene was assessed due to its conservation across SUMO family members and its surface exposure. Depletion of SUMO4 using siRNA, followed by complementation with the M55V variant, resulted in defective formation of 53BP1 and RAD51 foci. This indicated compromised homologous recombination (HR) repair capabilities in the context of DNA double-strand breaks (DSB). The study demonstrated that SUMO4 functions as a buffer in the SUMOylation system, and the findings highlighted the important role of the M55 position in DSB repair mechanisms.
title: SUMO4 regulates DNA double-strand break repair independently of conjugation

finding: The rs713031 SNP within the HLA-B gene exhibited random allele expression over time, revealing an allelic imbalance favoring the alternative allele at 24 hours post-infection (hpi) with a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 10, and a switch to the reference allele at 48 hpi with a 0.1 MOI. This finding highlighted the dynamic nature of allele expression in response to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: Differential haplotype expression in class I MHC genes during SARS-CoV-2 infection of human lung cell lines

finding: For the rs2071876 SNP in the BRD2 gene, a consistent expression of the reference allele was observed in the H522 cell line at both 72 and 96 hours post-infection (MOI = 0.06), indicating its role in the transcriptional response to SARS-CoV-2.
title: Differential haplotype expression in class I MHC genes during SARS-CoV-2 infection of human lung cell lines

finding: The SNP rs41553715 in the HLA-B gene showed an increased expression of the alternative allele despite a general increase in gene expression at 12 hpi. A preferential expression of the reference allele was noted at 48 hpi during the upregulation of the gene, suggesting a complex allele-specific expression mechanism influenced by the SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: Differential haplotype expression in class I MHC genes during SARS-CoV-2 infection of human lung cell lines

finding: The rs41550715 in the HLA-C gene revealed that, regardless of compensatory gene expression observed, the alternative allele was preferentially expressed in A549 cell lines during the studies, indicating significant effects of this SNP on HLA expression profiles under viral stress.
title: Differential haplotype expression in class I MHC genes during SARS-CoV-2 infection of human lung cell lines

finding: The SNP rs2075684-T-A found in the HLA-A gene was differentially expressed during viral infection in iBCs-1566 cells after 24 hpi, where the reference T allele was shown to be more active than the alternative A allele. This variation led to a phenotypic change at position 33 of the HLA-A protein, shifting from phenylalanine to tyrosine (Phe33Tyr).
title: Differential haplotype expression in class I MHC genes during SARS-CoV-2 infection of human lung cell lines

finding: In the context of the iBCs, rs45585732 was noted among the expression perturbations across related HLA-A variants, demonstrating changes in expression profiles during SARS-CoV-2 infection, emphasizing its potential role in HLA-A gene regulation.
title: Differential haplotype expression in class I MHC genes during SARS-CoV-2 infection of human lung cell lines

finding: The rs1655894 variant was also part of the altered expression landscape of HLA-A gene variants observed in iBCs, indicating that its expression levels were influenced by SARS-CoV-2 infection, thus contributing to our understanding of how HLA-A variations impact COVID-19 responses.
title: Differential haplotype expression in class I MHC genes during SARS-CoV-2 infection of human lung cell lines

finding: The SNP rs9380181 was identified in the MHC region and showed significant natural selection signals with a p-value of 2.04 × 10^-10, indicating its relevance in immune response mechanisms.
title: Genomic analyses of 10,376 individuals provides comprehensive map of genetic variations, structure and reference haplotypes for Chinese population

finding: The SNP rs615672 was identified as associated with rheumatoid arthritis, a significant autoimmune disease. It was part of an interacting pair with rs9268831 which was present in potential genome regulatory elements, suggesting its involvement in local gene-gene interactions.
title: Detecting epistatic interactions in genomic data using Random Forests

finding: The SNP rs9268831 was found to be part of an interactive pair with rs615672, both of which are located in potential genome regulatory elements. This interaction indicates that these SNPs may play a role in cis-acting regulatory mechanisms related to autoimmune disease pathways.
title: Detecting epistatic interactions in genomic data using Random Forests

finding: The SNP rs9273363 was noted for its association with several autoimmune diseases including rheumatoid arthritis and type 1 diabetes, indicating its potential significance in the genetic mechanisms underlying these conditions.
title: Detecting epistatic interactions in genomic data using Random Forests

finding: The SNP rs6457617 was associated with multiple sclerosis, Graves disease, and systemic sclerosis, highlighting its importance as a genetic marker in various autoimmune disorders.
title: Detecting epistatic interactions in genomic data using Random Forests

finding: The SNP rs2023239 was identified as being part of a linkage disequilibrium block in intron 2 of the CNR1 gene. This SNP was associated with several addictive behaviors, depression, psychosis, reduced hippocampal volume in cannabis abuse, nicotine addiction, obesity, and alcohol abuse, highlighting its significant role in these phenotypes.
title: Genetic and epigenetic influences modulating the tissue specific regulation of the cannabinoid receptor -1 gene (CB1); implications for cannabinoid pharmacogenetics

finding: Similar to rs2023239, rs9450898 was also located within the linkage disequilibrium block and was associated with addictive behaviors such as alcohol abuse, alongside depression, psychosis, and nicotine addiction. This positioned it as a key SNP in understanding the genetic predisposition to these conditions.
title: Genetic and epigenetic influences modulating the tissue specific regulation of the cannabinoid receptor -1 gene (CB1); implications for cannabinoid pharmacogenetics

finding: The SNP rs9444584 was characterized within the conserved regulatory sequence ECR1 in intron 2 of the CNR1 gene. It was found to be in high linkage disequilibrium with rs2023239 and rs9450898, and functional analyses indicated it had a significant impact on CNR1 expression in the hippocampus, influencing behaviors associated with alcohol intake and possibly providing a genetic basis for the differences in pharmacogenetic responses.
title: Genetic and epigenetic influences modulating the tissue specific regulation of the cannabinoid receptor -1 gene (CB1); implications for cannabinoid pharmacogenetics

finding: The SNP rs1003260 was identified in a GWAS with P<sub>GWAS</sub> = 3.6E-08, associated with the gene RIMS1 (P<sub>TWAS</sub> = 2.1E-08). This connection was significant as it highlighted RIMS1's role in osteoporosis indicating it as a potentially valuable target for future studies.
title: Integrating genome-wide association and transcriptome predicted model identify novel target genes with osteoporosis

finding: The SNP rs12203383 was identified in the study by Li et al. (2020) as significant in the context of phenological shifts in response to climatic changes, particularly relating to grassland spring phenology on the Qinghai–Tibetan Plateau. This finding connected the genetic variant to ecological changes, thereby contributing to understanding how certain genetic markers influence phenological responses in plants, with implications for broader ecological dynamics.
title: Fungal spore seasons advanced across the US over two decades of climate change

finding: The SNP rs9486719 was identified as the lead variant at the UFL1-FHL5 locus and was significantly associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) with a p-value of 1.1E-8 and myocardial infarction (MI) with a p-value of 6.8E-10. It was found to modulate FHL5 gene expression in artery tissues, where the risk allele (G) increased expression, implicating it as a crucial factor in vascular disease risk.
title: FHL5 controls vascular disease-associated gene programs in smooth muscle cells

finding: The SNP rs10872018 was prioritized as a causal variant at the UFL1-FHL5 locus. It was located in an active FHL5 regulatory element and increased luciferase activity in a functional assay. This SNP was associated with the expression of downstream genes involved in CAD/MI and was shown to disrupt a binding motif for the SRF-Myocardin complex, linking it to changes in vascular function.
title: FHL5 controls vascular disease-associated gene programs in smooth muscle cells

finding: The rs2274911 polymorphism in the GPRC6A gene was associated with insulin resistance in both normal weight and obese subjects. This finding highlighted the genetic variant's role in metabolic regulation and provided a novel risk factor for testis failure, which was corroborated by another study.
title: GPRC6A is a Potential Therapeutic Target for Metformin Regulation of Glucose Homeostasis in Mice

finding: The rs13215402 variant A allele decreased enhancer activity by 50% compared to the reference G allele, indicating a repressive effect on transcription factors relevant to prostate cancer gene regulation.
title: Optimized high-throughput screening of non-coding variants identified from genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs10484554, situated in the HLA-C gene, was shown to interact significantly with the SNP rs27524 from the ERAP1 gene, resulting in high odds ratios of greater than 7.5 for psoriasis. The interaction highlighted that the risk allele of rs27524 has a pronounced effect only in individuals who also carry at least one copy of the risk allele at rs10484554, underscoring the necessity of evaluating gene combinations in the genetic susceptibility to complex traits.
title: GWAIS-Web: A Fast and Secure Web Service for Epistasis Detection in Genome-wide Association Interaction Studies

finding: The common functional variant rs1360780 was associated with altered cognitive function in aged individuals, suggesting its impact on mechanisms relevant to Alzheimer's disease risk.
title: Late-Life Alcohol Exposure Does Not Exacerbate Age-Dependent Reductions in Mouse Spatial Memory and Brain TFEB Activity

finding: The SNP rs1165834930 (G/C) was linked to the activity of the SPDEF enhancer, showing a significant increase in enhancer activity by 5.0-fold. This SNP was located in the third KLF5 binding site and was identified as having one of the largest effects among all tested variants. This finding highlighted the role of variations in binding sites for transcription factors like KLF5 and STAT6 in mediating the enhancer's response to IL-13, which is critical in the pathophysiology of asthma.
title: Targeting a central feature of asthma using a cell type-selective IL-13-responsive enhancer

finding: The SNP rs2076309 was identified as being under strong selection and favored for myopia risk in the context of common refractive errors, highlighting its association with sustained selective pressure.
title: Detection of adaptation to light environment in myopia-associated loci Diversity of the myopia genetic background

finding: The SNP rs953413 was shown to regulate polyunsaturated fatty acid metabolism by modulating ELOVL2 expression, linking it to fatty acid composition in hepatic lipids.
title: HNF4α regulates acyl chain remodeling and ether lipid accumulation in hepatic steatosis

finding: The SNP rs13215498 was identified as a positive and original finding related to ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T). This particular SNP was associated with the functioning of the ATM protein, highlighting its role in DNA damage response and potential implications in neuroblastoma. The study linked the genetic variation to the pathology of A-T, specifically to the neural atrophy and abnormal microtubule dynamics observed in ATM-null cells.
title: The ataxia-telangiectasia disease protein ATM controls vesicular protein secretion via CHGA and microtubule dynamics via CRMP5

finding: The SNP rs13194932 was associated with the progression of pancreatic cancer and was identified as a positive finding in the context of the tumor microenvironment's heterogeneity influencing therapy response.
title: Understanding and leveraging phenotypic plasticity during metastasis formation

finding: The SNP rs12203592 located in intron 4 of the gene Irf4 was genetically linked to the phenotype of human hair graying, a condition attributed to the loss of melanocyte stem cells (McSCs). This SNP disrupted an intronic enhancer element critical for the transcription of the Irf4 gene, which is regulated in cooperation with MITF to influence Tyr expression. Research indicated that the loss of Irf4 resulted in lighter hair color in Mitf mutant mice. Within the study's context of qMcSCs, Irf4 expression was observed only in the most differentiated subpopulation, indicating its role in differentiation status among McSC populations.
title: Molecular heterogeneity of quiescent melanocyte stem cells revealed by single-cell RNA-sequencing

finding: The study noted an association between rs9349379 in the PHACTR1 gene and coronary artery disease, indicating its potential role in the development of this condition.
title: Screening and identification of key biomarkers in diabetic kidney disease and its complications: Evidence from bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The SNP rs1360780, located within intron 2 of the human FKBP5 gene, was found to modulate FKBP5 demethylation and transcription. This modulation was associated with susceptibility to stress-related psychiatric disorders, highlighting the role of GR in influencing mental health through epigenetic mechanisms.
title: Regulation of neuron-specific gene transcription by stress hormone signalling requires synaptic activity in zebrafish

finding: The SNP rs11967262, lying in an intergenic region upstream of VEGFA, was found to be significantly associated with varicose veins (VVs) with a P-value of 1.45×10^-19.
title: Genome-wide association analysis and replication in 810,625 individuals identifies novel therapeutic targets for varicose veins

finding: The SNP rs2842611 was identified as a HDL-associated SNP located in an intron of the neighboring gene SNX15. Its cis-regulatory effect was linked to the expression level of the lncRNA SNHG5, which is down-regulated in adipose tissue from patients with obesity. This finding highlighted a complex regulation mechanism involving SNHG5, illustrating that traditional GWAS approaches based solely on chromosomal coordinates may overlook important regulatory contexts.
title: Context Dependent Perturbation of Allelic Expression Imbalance Reveals Novel Candidate Therapeutic Targets for Metabolic diseases

finding: Residing in EYA4, rs9493627 is a missense SNP that showed a strong association with hearing difficulty (p = 7.7e-10) in the UK Biobank dataset. This finding highlighted its connection to Mendelian forms of hearing loss.
title: Biological insights from multi-omic analysis of 31 genomic risk loci for adult hearing difficulty

finding: The polymorphic rs9471643 was shown to upregulate PGC transcription and protein expression, supporting its involvement in cancer susceptibility, especially in dominant or overdominant genetic models.
title: SNPector: SNP inspecting tool to detect disease existence and drug response in direct naked sequencing depends on mutation index

finding: Similar to rs9471643, the rs6458238 variant was also found to upregulate PGC transcription and protein expression, further evidencing its potential association with cancer risk.
title: SNPector: SNP inspecting tool to detect disease existence and drug response in direct naked sequencing depends on mutation index

finding: The study identified a significant association between the rs10455872 SNP and Lp(a) levels among individuals in the UK Biobank cohort. It indicated that the relative increase in Lp(a) levels was statistically significant regardless of whether raw or adjusted Lp(a) levels were analyzed, and this was consistent across various analytical methods and populations. The rs10455872 SNP had been previously recognized in multiple genome-wide association studies as a top association with elevated Lp(a) levels, thereby supporting its role in influencing Lp(a) concentration.
title: Functional interrogation of cellular Lp(a) uptake by genome-scale CRISPR screening

finding: The SNP rs3135388 was used to tag the HLA-DRB1*15:01 risk variant, which was confirmed to be associated with an earlier age at onset of multiple sclerosis (AAO). Carriers of this allele were found to have an onset that was one year younger on average compared to non-carriers (p<0.001).
title: A higher burden of multiple sclerosis genetic risk confers an earlier onset

finding: The SNP rs28672722 was identified as a lead independent risk variant near HLA-DQB1, with a significant association to AAO (p=6.9×10^-7). It contributed to the understanding of genetic risk variants linked to earlier onset of multiple sclerosis.
title: A higher burden of multiple sclerosis genetic risk confers an earlier onset

finding: This SNP was found within COL21A1 and associated with a significantly earlier AAO of multiple sclerosis by an average of 7.5 years (p<0.001). This was noted as one of three less common variants exhibiting strong effects on AAO.
title: A higher burden of multiple sclerosis genetic risk confers an earlier onset

finding: The SNP rs719316 was associated with significant effects on AAO (p=0.020), suggesting a link between genetic variation in ATXN1 and clinically relevant aspects of multiple sclerosis.
title: A higher burden of multiple sclerosis genetic risk confers an earlier onset

finding: The SNP rs12195276 in the KCNQ5 gene showed a significant association with variation in pulse pressure. This association underscores the role of M-current in modulating sympathetic nervous system responses, particularly in cardiovascular metrics affected by adrenergic signaling.
title: Novel target identification using single cell sequencing and electrophysiology of cardiac sympathetic neurons in disease

finding: The T108A variant (rs376205580) in the A20 gene was identified in a subset of healthy individuals of Māori or Pacific Islander ancestry within the study cohort. This variant was part of a rare allele linked to a beneficial tolerance mechanism, thus demonstrating a possible advantageous adaptation in these populations.
title: Phospho-tuning immunity through Denisovan, modern human and mouse TNFAIP3 gene variants

finding: The I207L variant (rs141807543) was also found in conjunction with T108A in healthy individuals of Māori or Pacific Islander ancestry. Similar to T108A, this variant was part of a rare allele that suggested enhanced immune response without the detrimental effects of some other A20 variants, thus contributing to a balance of immunity and tolerance.
title: Phospho-tuning immunity through Denisovan, modern human and mouse TNFAIP3 gene variants

finding: The SNP rs2764208 was indicated as a lead variant influencing the i2-rQTL effect on SNRPC isoforms, which were co-localized with systemic lupus erythematosus GWAS risk alleles, suggesting a role in immune response regulation.
title: Splicing QTL analysis focusing on coding sequences reveals pathogenicity of disease susceptibility loci

finding: The variant rs1180775074 showed a strong connection as an i2-rQTL variant on SNRPC, believed to influence interferon signature gene expression in systemic lupus erythematosus.
title: Splicing QTL analysis focusing on coding sequences reveals pathogenicity of disease susceptibility loci

finding: The eQTL variant rs2764197 presented with lower RTC scores compared to rs1180775074 but was still instrumental in the context of the UHRF1BP1 gene related to systemic lupus erythematosus.
title: Splicing QTL analysis focusing on coding sequences reveals pathogenicity of disease susceptibility loci

finding: The FHL5-associated SNP rs9373978 was replicated consistently across datasets, suggesting its involvement in functional brain networks.
title: Common variants contribute to intrinsic human brain functional networks

finding: The SNP rs2187668 was associated with the HLA-DRB1*03:01 haplotype and contributed positively to a Genetic Risk Score (GRS) that predicted susceptibility to Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This association was significant within the European cohort, suggesting its relevance in predicting SLE risk.
title: Genome-wide assessment of genetic risk for systemic lupus erythematosus and disease severity

finding: The SNP rs9267992 was linked to the HLA-DRB1*15:01 haplotype. Its inclusion in the GRS revealed a positive association with the risk of developing Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) also confirmed in the European population, underlining its importance in genetic susceptibility to the disease.
title: Genome-wide assessment of genetic risk for systemic lupus erythematosus and disease severity

finding: The SNP rs9271366 was part of the analysis in the Chinese population and contributed to the GRS for SLE, indicating its role in enhancing susceptibility to the disease. This finding was significant, highlighting its relevance across different populations.
title: Genome-wide assessment of genetic risk for systemic lupus erythematosus and disease severity

finding: The SNP rs9275328 was another key SNP that involved HLA-DQB1 and was significant in the Chinese cohort. Its contribution to the GRS for SLE suggested a strong genetic influence on susceptibility, affirming its positive association with the disease in the studied populations.
title: Genome-wide assessment of genetic risk for systemic lupus erythematosus and disease severity

finding: The SNP rs17612852 was associated with the expression of HLA-DQB1, underscoring its relevance in the context of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II antigen presentation, which is crucial for immune response modulation.
title: Germline modifiers of the tumor immune microenvironment implicate drivers of cancer risk and immunotherapy response

finding: The SNP rs144679016 was part of a set of seven variants identified in a constraint analysis of CAD GWAS. It was located in a highly constrained non-coding region related to the gene PLG, which encodes a protein involved in blood clot dissolution. This finding supported its role in increasing CAD risk through alterations in the regulatory elements of PLG.
title: A genome-wide mutational constraint map quantified from variation in 76,156 human genomes

finding: Similar to rs144679016, the SNP rs116480834 was also identified in the same set of CAD-related variants located in a constrained non-coding region connected to the PLG gene, implicating it in the genetic risk for CAD through regulatory mechanisms.
title: A genome-wide mutational constraint map quantified from variation in 76,156 human genomes

finding: The SNP rs10945688 was among the variants identified in a constrained region related to the PLG gene within the context of CAD risk. It contributed to the understanding of genetic variations that influence CAD susceptibility.
title: A genome-wide mutational constraint map quantified from variation in 76,156 human genomes

finding: The SNP rs148517610 was part of the variants studied within the highly constrained non-coding regions linked to the gene PLG. This finding aligns with previous studies suggesting its involvement in the pathogenesis of CAD.
title: A genome-wide mutational constraint map quantified from variation in 76,156 human genomes

finding: The SNP rs143556831 resided in the 9th intron of the PLG gene, indicating its relevance in the genetic architecture of CAD in light of recent constraint analyses.
title: A genome-wide mutational constraint map quantified from variation in 76,156 human genomes

finding: Identified as one of the variants from the highly constrained regions related to the PLG gene, the SNP rs12529023 was associated with distal regulatory effects in the context of CAD.
title: A genome-wide mutational constraint map quantified from variation in 76,156 human genomes

finding: The SNP rs139095347 was another variant from the set associated with the PLG gene's regulatory elements in the context of CAD, reinforcing the connection of non-coding variants to this disease.
title: A genome-wide mutational constraint map quantified from variation in 76,156 human genomes

finding: The variant rs11755393, an A to G change located on chromosome 6 at position 34824636, was confirmed as a true positive finding due to the increasing allele frequency of the alternative allele (G) from 0.132 in individuals without disease to 0.511 in those with CIN3. This indicates a correlation with disease progression. The analysis identified that the absence of a homopolymer sequence in the flanking region adjacent to the variant suggested reliable sequencing results. The study emphasized the effectiveness of various sequencing platforms in consistently identifying this variant.
title: VisVariant: A java program to visualise genetic variants in next-generation sequencing data

finding: This SNP was identified as an eQTL for HLA-DQB1 in monocytes and also showed associations in microglia, indicating a versatile role in immune-related expression patterns.
title: Allele-specific analysis reveals exon- and cell-type-specific regulatory effects of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants

finding: The variant rs1897107 was identified within a highly constrained genomic window associated with coronary artery disease (CAD). It showed a high constraint score (Z=6.32) and was part of a set of variants that spanned approximately 153 kb downstream of the gene PLG, which encodes the plasminogen protein involved in fibrin breakdown in blood clots. This finding provided quantitative support for the involvement of PLG in CAD.
title: A genome-wide mutational constraint map quantified from variation in 76,156 human genomes

finding: Similar to rs1897107, the variant rs1897109 was located within the same constrained genomic region linked to coronary artery disease (CAD), exhibiting a high constraint score (Z=6.32). It highlighted the potential regulatory significance of non-coding variants in the PLG gene, further implying its role in CAD progression through the dysregulation of the plasminogen–plasmin system.
title: A genome-wide mutational constraint map quantified from variation in 76,156 human genomes

finding: SNP rs9272785 (HLA-DQA1 gene) generated the most significant association in both MA and EA PheWAS, linked with 'rheumatoid arthritis' and various diabetes manifestations, indicating its impact across several disease phenotypes.
title: Multi-ancestry Genome- and Phenome-wide Association Studies of Diverticular Disease in Electronic Health Records with Natural Language Processing enriched phenotype algorithm

finding: Possession of the alternative allele for SNP rs4880, located in the superoxide dismutase 2 (SOD2) gene, was shown to be associated with shorter telomeres, highlighting a genetic influence on aging at the molecular level.
title: Markers, Mechanisms and Metrics of Biological Aging: A Scoping Review

finding: The SNP rs275350 was noted for its significant association with PVWMH; it is found intronically in the PLEKHG1 gene and is an eQTL for this gene.
title: Common genetic variation indicates separate etiologies for periventricular and deep white matter hyperintensities

finding: The SNP rs6570507 was associated with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS) in a multi-ethnic meta-analysis. This association highlighted the genetic contribution to the disorder, supporting the role of genetic factors in the pathogenesis of AIS, especially concerning the structural components of the axial skeleton and related connective tissues.
title: A G protein-coupled receptor is required in cartilaginous and dense connective tissues to maintain spine alignment

finding: The deepSNP rs62420820 was associated with multiple sclerosis (MS), showing genome-wide significance in the IMSGC GWAS (p-value=9.26×10^{-36}) and nominal significance in the KKNMS GWAS (p-value=1.23×10^{-5}). It was found in the intergenic region IL20RA-IL22RA2 and implicated in allele-specific transcription factor (TF) binding differences for MafF and MafK.
title: DeepWAS: Multivariate genotype-phenotype associations by directly integrating regulatory information using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs1264326 was associated with risk for inflammatory acne rosacea and acted as an eQTL for DDR1, enhancing TFAP2A binding which could lead to increased transcription of pro-inflammatory genes.
title: Disease-Linked Regulatory DNA Variants and Homeostatic Transcription Factors in Epidermis

finding: Associated with ZSCAN genes, this SNP was correlated with several health issues and showed strong associations with psychiatric disorders as seen in the UK Biobank.
title: Brain aging comprises multiple modes of structural and functional change with distinct genetic and biophysical associations

finding: Found to correlate with snoring; this SNP illustrated various lifestyle factors associated with sleep patterns and possibly cardiovascular health.
title: Brain aging comprises multiple modes of structural and functional change with distinct genetic and biophysical associations

finding: Linked to hypertension and migraines; this SNP showed a strong correlation with cardiovascular health risks in the UK Biobank.
title: Brain aging comprises multiple modes of structural and functional change with distinct genetic and biophysical associations

finding: Allele A in rs240764 was associated with more frequent neurotic behavior and overlapped with loci formerly associated with mental disorders. This finding highlighted a connection between this SNP and the predisposition to specific psychological traits, which may be related to survey nonresponse.
title: Patterns of item nonresponse behavior to survey questionnaires are systematic and have a genetic basis

finding: The SNP rs2229634 in the ITPR3 gene was reported to be associated with an increased risk of developing coronary artery aneurysm in children diagnosed with Kawasaki disease. This finding underscored the significance of genetic variants in influencing complex phenotypes, particularly in pediatric contexts.
title: IBAS: Interaction-bridged association studies discovering novel genes underlying complex traits

finding: The SNP rs176713 was associated with the BACH2 gene, a transcriptional inhibitor known to impact Nrf2 function, which is believed to provide a protective effect against neurodegeneration in Parkinson's disease.
title: CluStrat: a structure informed clustering strategy for population stratification

finding: The SNP rs9268645 was highlighted as significant for RA, affecting the FKBPL gene's expression in whole blood, suggesting a regulatory role in inflammation and vascular integrity.
title: Identification and catalogue of viral transcriptional regulators in human diseases

finding: The rs3778150 SNP was associated with opioid addiction and was found to overlap with a human-specific upregulated enhancer within the OPRM1 locus. This enhancer exhibited changes in gene expression that were specific to glutamatergic neurons in humans. Notably, the major allele of rs3778150 (T>C) reflected a strictly human-specific substitution, further supporting its role in changes related to substance abuse.
title: Evolution of regulatory signatures in primate cortical neurons at cell type resolution

finding: The rs1799971 SNP was associated with opioid abuse and was located within a human-specific upregulated promoter of the OPRM1 gene. The study observed a human-specific nucleotide substitution (C>T) at the SNP position and noted that this site displayed high conservation across mammals. The findings linked this SNP to significant evolutionary changes in the OPRM1 regulatory landscape and corresponding alterations in opioid-relevant gene expression.
title: Evolution of regulatory signatures in primate cortical neurons at cell type resolution

finding: The SNP rs699947 in the promoter region of VEGFA exhibited significant genetic divergence between Sherpa highlanders and non-Sherpa lowlanders, as well as across global populations. The finding indicated that the major allele C was more prevalent in Sherpas, contributing to their hypoxia tolerance through optimal VEGF-A production at high altitudes.
title: Hypoxia-tolerant vascular endothelial growth factor-A (VEGF-A) and the genetic variations of VEGFA in Sherpa highlanders

finding: Similar to rs699947 and rs8333061, the SNP rs1570360 in the promoter region displayed significant genetic divergence. The major allele G was frequently linked with adaptive responses to hypoxia among Sherpas, supporting their unique physiological adaptation mechanisms at high altitudes.
title: Hypoxia-tolerant vascular endothelial growth factor-A (VEGF-A) and the genetic variations of VEGFA in Sherpa highlanders

finding: The SNP rs2010963 in the 5'-UTR presented significant differences in allele frequency between Sherpas and lowlanders. This SNP contributed to the regulation of VEGFA gene expression, reinforcing the genetic basis of hypoxia tolerance found in Sherpa highlanders.
title: Hypoxia-tolerant vascular endothelial growth factor-A (VEGF-A) and the genetic variations of VEGFA in Sherpa highlanders

finding: The SNP rs833061, like rs699947 and rs1570360, demonstrated significant genetic divergence and was linked to hypoxia tolerance. The major allele, T, was found to be more frequent in Sherpa highlanders, indicating its role in regulating VEGFA under hypoxic conditions.
title: Hypoxia-tolerant vascular endothelial growth factor-A (VEGF-A) and the genetic variations of VEGFA in Sherpa highlanders

finding: The SNP rs10455872 was associated with increased risks of hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular diseases. In a comparative phenome-wide association study (PheWAS) conducted using both ICD-9-CM and ICD-10-CM mappings, significant positive correlations were found between the minor allele of rs10455872 and coronary atherosclerosis (p < 0.001, OR = 1.60 for both mappings) as well as chronic ischemic heart disease (p < 0.001, OR = 1.56 for ICD-9-CM and p < 0.001, OR = 1.47 for ICD-10-CM). This highlighted the reliability of the ICD-10-CM to phecode mapping in identifying important genetic associations related to cardiovascular phenotypes.
title: Developing and Evaluating Mappings of ICD-10 and ICD-10-CM Codes to Phecodes

finding: The rs2790099-C variant was associated with white matter volume in regions of the basal ganglia and suggested to play a role as a potential cis-eQTL for RUNX2.
title: Deep learning based brain age prediction uncovers associated sequence variants

finding: The rs2184968-C variant correlated with increased cerebrospinal fluid in subcortical regions and was noted for associations with traits such as height and cognitive performance.
title: Deep learning based brain age prediction uncovers associated sequence variants

finding: The SNP rs910416 was identified as falling within a cell-constrained domain characterized by significant H3K27me3 repression across various cell types. It was associated with a PIP score of 1 in the continuous cellular constraint score model, indicating its functional importance, in contrast to a PIP score of 0 in a non-functional model. This intronic non-coding variant is located in the Estrogen Receptor 1 (ESR1) locus and has a causal, experimentally validated association with breast cancer. It was shown that rs910416 is situated within a putative silencer element, where allele-specific binding of MYC due to this SNP disrupts the silencer's function in regulating both ESR1 and RMND1 expression, subsequently contributing to breast cancer development.
title: Epigenetic constraint of cellular genomes evolutionarily links genetic variation to function

finding: The SNP rs75932628, representing the rare TREM2 R47H missense variant, was previously associated with late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) in multiple independent studies. In the context of the analysis, male Trem2 R47H mice exhibited a significantly negative association with immune-related human co-expression modules in several brain regions, notably the superiortemporal gyrus and the prefrontal cortex. This negative correlation became more pronounced between six and 14 months, indicating a potential progression of immune dysfunction related to this variant.
title: A novel systems biology approach to evaluate mouse models of late-onset Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs1236009877, located in the IFNGR1 gene, was initially categorized as an intronic variant with low severity in the Ensembl/GENCODE transcript set. However, after reannotation with a custom transcriptome, it was identified as a stop-gain variant with high severity, demonstrating its likely pathogenicity related to IFNGR1 deficiency. This variant was confirmed to be expressed in all sequenced samples, with sufficient supporting reads, indicating it was not an artifact. The affected transcript had a coding probability of 0.934, marking it as a credible ORF.
title: SUsPECT: A pipeline for variant effect prediction based on custom long-read transcriptomes for improved clinical variant annotation

finding: The SNP rs6923262 was identified as part of a trans-omic path involving the gene SRF and the APP peptide 2, indicating its relevance in the context of Alzheimer's disease.
title: Deep multi-omic network fusion for marker discovery of Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The research extended to patient-specific neurons with the PRKN mutation (homozygous p.R275W, rs34424986), where treatment with 2-Hydroxypropyl-β-Cyclodextrin (HP-β-CD) resulted in increased differentiation efficiency into TH+ neurons, suggesting a broader potential application of this treatment for different PD-causing mutations.
title: Parkinson’s disease phenotypes in patient specific brain organoids are improved by HP-β-CD treatment

finding: The SNP rs2105898 was shown to harbor a genetic signal that was independent of C4 effects, significantly contributing to the risk of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and Sjögren's syndrome (SjS). In analyses adjusting for C4 effects, this haplotype was associated with an increased SLE risk, showing an odds ratio of 1.52 (95% CI: 1.44-1.61; p < 10^-48) in Europeans and 1.49 (95% CI: 1.35-1.63; p < 10^-16) in African Americans. Furthermore, this SNP was closely linked to increased expression of HLA class II genes which are pivotal in autoimmune responses, thus implicating it in the pathogenesis of these autoimmune diseases.
title: Complement component 4 genes contribute sex-specific vulnerability in diverse illnesses

finding: The SNP rs13205174 was associated with new insights into NKT cell immunotherapy as described in CRC studies. This finding underscored the role of genetic variants in influencing immune responses to therapies targeting NKT cells in the context of colorectal cancer.
title: Immunophenotypic changes in peripheral blood of colorectal cancer patients: a potential diagnostic marker for CD4+ monocytes

finding: The rs1979 SNP was found to be associated with the downregulation of the S-linked LtWDR-44 candidate gene, which is linked to male self-incompatibility and anther height in Linum trigynum. This finding indicated that mutations affecting this gene could underpin the transition to homostyly and self-compatibility in this species, contrasting with its distylous relatives.
title: Genetic causes and genomic consequences of breakdown of distyly in Linum trigynum

finding: This SNP in the TNF region was associated with 11 bacteriophage groups, suggesting its potential role in shaping phage communities through immune response pathways.
title: Triadic Dynamics of Gastric Bacterial Microbiome, Phageome, and Host Genotype, with Implications for Disease Associations

finding: The SNP rs35571244 was recognized as the primary cis-eQTL for the gene <italic>PBX2</italic>, establishing its relevance in network analyses of subcutaneous fat.
title: Gene networks driven by genetic variation for plasma cortisol in hepatic and adipose tissues implicate corticosteroid binding globulin in modulating tissue glucocorticoid action and cardiovascular risk

finding: The SNP rs443198 was significantly associated with systemic sclerosis (M34) and mapped to the gene NOTCH4. This gene was noted for its associations with multiple diseases in the musculoskeletal system and connective tissue, including rheumatoid arthritis (M06.9), psoriatic arthritis (M07.3), Takayasu arteritis (M31.4), systemic lupus erythematosus (M32.9), and appendicular lean mass (M62.9).
title: A novel method for multiple phenotype association studies based on genotype and phenotype network

finding: The SNP rs241458 was associated with rheumatoid arthritis pathway. It was noted as part of a group of SNPs identified through network-based tests, enhancing understanding of disease architecture.
title: A novel method for multiple phenotype association studies based on genotype and phenotype network

finding: The SNP rs3097646 was linked to enriched genes in the rheumatoid arthritis pathway, and it was recognized as part of the network analysis that identified additional associations compared to standard tests.
title: A novel method for multiple phenotype association studies based on genotype and phenotype network

finding: The SNP rs6916921 was also reported in the GWAS Catalog with associations to diseases in the musculoskeletal system; however, specific associations were not detailed in this context.
title: A novel method for multiple phenotype association studies based on genotype and phenotype network

finding: The SNP rs13195028 was found to be associated with the LAMC2-positive cancer stem cell population in pancreatic cancer. This specific SNP was correlated with the enhanced self-renewal capacity of tumor-initiating cells, which are pivotal for tumor initiation, differentiation, and driving metastasis. The findings indicated that this SNP might serve as a potential biomarker for SPLC identification and suggest a therapeutic target for interventions in pancreatic cancer.
title: LAMC2 marks a tumor-initiating cell population with an aggressive signature in pancreatic cancer

finding: This SNP was associated with the expression of the gene TFAP2B, linking it to metabolic processes related to nephrolithiasis.
title: GWAS identifies nine nephrolithiasis susceptibility loci related with metabolic metabolic and crystallization pathways

finding: Associated with the EPB41L2 gene on 6q23.2, rs6928986 was implicated in the regulation of PTHR localization and activity, affecting nephrolithiasis.
title: GWAS identifies nine nephrolithiasis susceptibility loci related with metabolic metabolic and crystallization pathways

finding: This SNP, located within the KCNK5 gene on 6p21.2, was linked to distal tubular acidosis in mice, suggesting its role in altering urine pH and affecting stone formation.
title: GWAS identifies nine nephrolithiasis susceptibility loci related with metabolic metabolic and crystallization pathways

finding: The SNP rs760676508 was associated with an in-frame deletion located in exon 14 of RIPOR2 (c.1696_1707del; p.(Gln566_Lys569del)). This variant was identified as a highly penetrant cause of adult-onset progressive hearing loss that segregated as an autosomal dominant trait in 12 families from the Netherlands. The hearing loss phenotype was marked by variable audiometric characteristics and an average onset age of 30.6 years. Functional studies indicated aberrant localization of the mutant RIPOR2 protein in the cochlear hair cells, underscoring its pathogenic role.
title: A RIPOR2 in-frame deletion is a frequent and highly penetrant cause of adult-onset hearing loss

finding: This SNP was identified as a notable candidate for osteoporosis risk due to its regulatory effects on TBX18 expression, showing association with bone density traits.
title: Osteoporosis- and obesity-risk interrelationships: An epigenetic analysis of GWAS-derived SNPs at the developmental gene TBX15

finding: Rs17792917 was highlighted for its association with osteoporosis risk, located near TBX18, indicating its potential role in influencing bone density via regulatory mechanisms.
title: Osteoporosis- and obesity-risk interrelationships: An epigenetic analysis of GWAS-derived SNPs at the developmental gene TBX15

finding: The rs7756992 A/G polymorphism in the CDKAL1 gene was discussed in a meta-analysis involving 62,567 subjects, indicating its association with type 2 diabetes mellitus. This suggests that variations in the CDKAL1 gene may be linked to metabolic dysregulation and could relate to the observed glucose dyshomeostasis resulting from NFS1 inhibition.
title: Acute inhibition of iron-sulfur cluster biosynthesis disrupts metabolic flexibility in mice

finding: A later study identified rs35612982 as a novel polymorphism in the CDKAL1 gene that serves as a risk factor for type 2 diabetes. This finding corroborates the earlier association of CDKAL1 with dysregulated metabolism and aligns with the metabolic impacts observed in mice with acute ISC inhibition.
title: Acute inhibition of iron-sulfur cluster biosynthesis disrupts metabolic flexibility in mice

finding: The SNP rs13215542 was associated with variations in the expression of CCR4, a chemokine receptor, which has been highlighted as a therapeutic target in cancer immunotherapy. This relationship was linked to breast cancer, indicating that variations at this locus could influence the tumor microenvironment and potentially affect patient outcomes.
title: CHEMOKINE SIGNALING IN BREAST CANCER: FOCUS ON CC-MOTIF CHEMOKINE LIGANDS

finding: The SNP rs13215492 was highlighted as a significant marker related to drug repositioning in the context of rectal cancer, specifically identifying TOP2A as a therapeutic target. This approach was linked to the reversal of gene expression signatures associated with the cancer.
title: Signature reversion of three disease-associated gene signatures prioritizes cancer drug repurposing candidates

finding: The SNP rs6557168 was found near the ESR1 locus, with a p-value of 1.04×10−9, indicating its association with anxiety in Europeans. This SNP highlights the role of estrogen receptor signaling in anxiety disorders.
title: Reproducible Risk Loci and Psychiatric Comorbidities in Anxiety: Results from ~200,000 Million Veteran Program Participants

finding: The SNP rs6570507 was identified as the lead SNP at the ADGRG6 locus, which associated with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS) susceptibility. It was found to overlap with H3K27ac ChIP-seq peaks, indicating its potential role as a regulatory element in gene expression related to musculoskeletal tissues of the spine. Additionally, functional analysis through luciferase assays in human SW1353 cells confirmed its involvement in activating enhancers at this locus, further supporting its relevance to AIS.
title: Genomic characterization of the adolescent idiopathic scoliosis associated transcriptome and regulome

finding: The SNP rs10949481 mapped to the 3'UTR of NHLRC1 on chromosome 6p22.3 was associated with the epigenetic biomarker IEAA, with a significant beta coefficient of -0.20 and a p-value of 4.5×10^-54. This association was noted as one of the top loci identified in prior meta-analyses of IEAA.
